    .cdx-button{display:inline-flex;align-items:center;justify-content:center;gap:4px;box-sizing:border-box;min-height:32px;max-width:28rem;margin:0;border-width:1px;border-style:solid;border-radius:2px;padding-right:11px;padding-left:11px;font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit;font-weight:700;overflow:hidden;text-overflow:ellipsis;white-space:nowrap;text-transform:none;transition-property:background-color,color,border-color,box-shadow;transition-duration:.1s}.cdx-button--size-large{min-height:44px;padding-right:15px;padding-left:15px}.cdx-button--icon-only{min-width:32px;padding-right:5px;padding-left:5px}.cdx-button--icon-only.cdx-button--size-large{min-width:44px;padding-right:11px;padding-left:11px}.cdx-button::-moz-focus-inner{border:0;padding:0}.cdx-button .cdx-button__icon,.cdx-button .cdx-icon{vertical-align:middle}.cdx-button .mwe-popups-title .popups-icon--reference-note{display:none}.mwe-popups.mwe-popups-type-reference .mwe-popups-container .mwe-popups-extract{margin-right:0;max-height:inherit}.mwe-popups.mwe-popups-type-reference .mwe-popups-container .mwe-popups-extract .mwe-popups-scroll{max-height:343px;overflow:auto;padding-right:16px}.mwe-popups.mwe-popups-type-reference .mwe-popups-container .mwe-popups-extract .mw-parser-output{overflow-wrap:break-word}.mwe-popups.mwe-popups-type-reference .mwe-popups-container .mwe-popups-extract::after{display:none}.mwe-popups.mwe-popups-type-reference .mwe-popups-container .mwe-popups-extract .mwe-popups-fade{position:absolute;width:100%;height:20px;background-color:transparent;background-image:linear-gradient(rgba(255,255,255,0),#ffffff);opacity:0;pointer-events:none;transition:opacity 250ms ease}.mwe-popups.mwe-popups-type-reference .mwe-popups-container .mwe-popups-extract.mwe-popups-fade-out .mwe-popups-fade{opacity:1}.mwe-popups.mwe-popups-type-reference .mwe-popups-container small font size</span></div></div><div class="mw-portlet mw-portlet-skin-client-prefs-vector-feature-limited-width vector-menu" id="skin-client-prefs-vector-feature-limited-width"><div                         <div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Island country in East Asia</div>
    <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1236090951">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Several terms  redirect here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Japan_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Japan (disambiguation)">Japan (disambiguation)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nihon_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Nihon (disambiguation)">Nihon (disambiguation)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nippon_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Nippon (disambiguation)">Nippon (disambiguation)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/JPN_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="JPN (disambiguation)">JPN (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

139.767</span></span></span></a></span></span></span></td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Official&nbsp;languages</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a> (<i>de facto</i>)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Demonym" title="Demonym">Demonym(s)</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Japan" title="Politics of Japan">Government</a></th><td class="infobox-data">Unitary <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_constitutional_monarchy" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliamentary constitutional monarchy">parliamentary constitutional monarchy</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><td colspan="2" class="infobox-full-data"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1237879389"></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Japan" title="Emperor of Japan">Emperor</a> </div></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Naruhito" title="Naruhito">Naruhito</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Japan" title="Prime Minister of Japan">Prime Minister</a> </div></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Fumio_Kishida" title="Fumio Kishida">Fumio Kishida</a></td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
    </td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Legislature</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/National_Diet" title="National Diet">National Diet</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Upper_house" title="Upper house">Upper house</a></div></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/House_of_Councillors_(Japan)" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Councillors (Japan)">House of Councillors</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Lower_house" title="Lower house">Lower house</a></div></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_(Japan)" title="House of Representatives (Japan)">House of Representatives</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th colspan="2" class="infobox-header"><a href="/wiki/History_of_Japan" title="History of Japan">Formation</a></th></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><td colspan="2" class="infobox-full-data"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1237879389"></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Meiji_Constitution" title="Meiji Constitution">Meiji Constitution</a> </div></th><td class="infobox-data">November 29, 1890</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;<span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">Current constitution</a></span> </div></th><td class="infobox-data">May 3, 1947</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
    </td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th colspan="2" class="infobox-header"><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Japan" title="Geography of Japan">Area </a></th></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" title=".jp">.jp</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
    <p><b>Japan</b><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>a<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> is an <a href="/wiki/Island_country" title="Island country">island country</a> in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>. It is located in the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> off the northeast coast of the <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asian mainland</a>, and is bordered on the west by the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a> and extends from the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Okhotsk" title="Sea of Okhotsk">Sea of Okhotsk</a> in the north to the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China Sea</a> in the south. The <a href="/wiki/Japanese_archipelago" title="Japanese archipelago">Japanese archipelago</a> consists of four major islands<a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">Hokkaido</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honshu" title="Honshu">Honshu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shikoku" title="Shikoku">Shikoku</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kyushu" title="Kyushu">Kyushu</a>and <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Japan" title="List of islands of Japan">thousands of smaller islands</a>, covering 377,975 square kilometres (145,937&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi). Japan has a population of nearly 124 million as of 2024, and is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">eleventh-most populous country</a>. <a href="/wiki/Capital_of_Japan" title="Capital of Japan">Its capital</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Japan" title="List of cities in Japan">largest city</a> is <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Tokyo_Area" title="Greater Tokyo Area">Greater Tokyo Area</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities" title="List of largest cities">largest metropolitan area</a> in the world, with more than 38 million inhabitants as of 2016. Japan is divided into 47 <a href="/wiki/Prefectures_of_Japan" title="Prefectures of Japan">administrative prefectures</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_regions_of_Japan" title="List of regions of Japan">eight traditional regions</a>. About three-quarters of <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Japan" title="Geography of Japan">the country's terrain</a> is mountainous and heavily forested, concentrating its agriculture and <a href="/wiki/Urbanization_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Urbanization by country">highly urbanized population</a> along its eastern <a href="/wiki/Coastal_plain" title="Coastal plain">coastal plains</a>. The country sits on the Pacific <a href="/wiki/Ring_of_Fire" title="Ring of Fire">Ring of Fire</a>, making its islands prone to destructive <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_Japan" title="List of earthquakes in Japan">earthquakes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tsunami" title="Tsunami">tsunamis</a>.
    </p><p>The first known habitation of the archipelago dates to the <a href="/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic">Upper Paleolithic</a>, with the beginning <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Paleolithic" title="Japanese Paleolithic">Japanese Paleolithic</a> dating to <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">36,000 BC</span>. Between the fourth and sixth centuries, its kingdoms were united under <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Japan" title="Emperor of Japan">an emperor</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nara_(city)" title="Nara (city)">Nara</a>, and later <a href="/wiki/Heian-ky%C5%8D" title="Heian-ky">Heian-ky</a>. From the 12th century, actual power was held by military dictators (<span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Shogun" title="Shogun">shgun</a></i></span>) and feudal lords (<span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Daimyo" title="Daimyo">daimy</a></i></span>), and enforced by warrior nobility (<i><a href="/wiki/Samurai" title="Samurai">samurai</a></i>). After rule by the <a href="/wiki/Kamakura_period" title="Kamakura period">Kamakura</a> and <a href="/wiki/Muromachi_period" title="Muromachi period">Ashikaga shogunates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sengoku_period" title="Sengoku period">a century of warring states</a>, Japan was unified in 1600 by the <a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_shogunate" title="Tokugawa shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a>, which implemented <a href="/wiki/Sakoku" title="Sakoku">an isolationist foreign policy</a>. In 1853, <a href="/wiki/Perry_Expedition" title="Perry Expedition">a United States fleet</a> forced Japan to <a href="/wiki/Bakumatsu" title="Bakumatsu">open trade to the West</a>, which led to the <a href="/wiki/Boshin_War" title="Boshin War">end of the shogunate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Restoration" title="Meiji Restoration">restoration of imperial power</a> in 1868. In the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_era" title="Meiji era">Meiji period</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a> pursued rapid <a href="/wiki/Industrialisation" title="Industrialisation">industrialization</a> and <a href="/wiki/Modernization_theory" title="Modernization theory">modernization</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Japanese_militarism" title="Japanese militarism">militarism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_colonial_empire" title="Japanese colonial empire">overseas colonization</a>. In 1937, Japan <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">invaded China</a>, and in 1941 <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attacked the United States</a> and European colonial powers, entering <a href="/wiki/Japan_during_World_War_II" title="Japan during World War II">World War II</a> as an <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis power</a>. After suffering defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_War" title="Pacific War">Pacific War</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki">two atomic bombings</a>, Japan <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">surrendered</a> in 1945 and came under <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Japan" title="Occupation of Japan">Allied occupation</a>. After the war, the country underwent <a href="/wiki/Japanese_economic_miracle" title="Japanese economic miracle">rapid economic growth</a>, although <a href="/wiki/Lost_Decades" title="Lost Decades">its economy has stagnated since 1990</a>.
    </p><p>Japan is a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> legislature, the <a href="/wiki/National_Diet" title="National Diet">National Diet</a>. A <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a> and the only Asian member of the <a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a>, Japan has constitutionally <a href="/wiki/Article_9_of_the_Japanese_Constitution" title="Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution">renounced its right to declare war</a>, but maintains <a href="/wiki/Japan_Self-Defense_Forces" title="Japan Self-Defense Forces">one of the world's strongest militaries</a>. A <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">highly developed country</a> with one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">largest economies</a>, Japan is a global leader in <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Japan" title="Science and technology in Japan">science and technology</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Japan" title="Automotive industry in Japan">automotive</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_robotics" title="Japanese robotics">robotics</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Electronics_industry_in_Japan" title="Electronics industry in Japan">electronics industries</a>. It has one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">highest life expectancies</a>, though it is undergoing <a href="/wiki/Aging_of_Japan" title="Aging of Japan">a population decline</a>. <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Japan" title="Culture of Japan">Japan's culture</a> is well known around the world, including <a href="/wiki/Japanese_art" title="Japanese art">its art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">cuisine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cinema" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese cinema">film</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Japan" title="Music of Japan">music</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_popular_culture" title="Japanese popular culture">popular culture</a>, which includes prominent <a href="/wiki/Manga" title="Manga">comics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">animation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Video_games_in_Japan" title="Video games in Japan">video game</a> industries.
    </p>
    <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><meta property="mw:PageProp/toc"></div>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Etymology">Etymology</h2></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Japan" title="Names of Japan">Names of Japan</a></div>
    <p>The name for Japan in <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a> is written using the <a href="/wiki/Kanji" title="Kanji">kanji</a> <span class="t_nihongo_kanji"><span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span></span> and is pronounced <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">Nihon</i></span> or <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">Nippon</i></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-schreiber_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-schreiber-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Before <span class="t_nihongo_kanji"><span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span></span> was adopted in the early 8th century, the country was known in China as <span title="Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="zh-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Wa_(Japan)" title="Wa (Japan)">Wa</a></i></span> (<span class="t_nihongo_kanji"><span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span></span>, changed in Japan around 757 to <span class="t_nihongo_kanji"><span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span></span>) and in Japan by the <a href="/wiki/Endonym" class="mw-redirect" title="Endonym">endonym</a> <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Yamato_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Yamato (disambiguation)">Yamato</a></i></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-carr_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carr-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">Nippon</i></span>, the original <a href="/wiki/Sino-Japanese_reading" class="mw-redirect" title="Sino-Japanese reading">Sino-Japanese reading</a> of the characters, is favored for official uses, including on <a href="/wiki/Banknotes_of_the_Japanese_yen" title="Banknotes of the Japanese yen">Japanese banknotes</a> and postage stamps.<sup id="cite_ref-schreiber_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-schreiber-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">Nihon</i></span> is typically used in everyday speech and reflects shifts in <a href="/wiki/Japanese_phonology" title="Japanese phonology">Japanese phonology</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Edo_period" title="Edo period">Edo period</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-carr_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carr-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The characters <span class="t_nihongo_kanji"><span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span></span> mean "sun origin",<sup id="cite_ref-schreiber_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-schreiber-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> which is the source of the popular Western <a href="/wiki/Epithet" title="Epithet">epithet</a> "Land of the Rising Sun".<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The name "Japan" is based on <a href="/wiki/Min_Chinese" title="Min Chinese">Min</a> or <a href="/wiki/Wu_Chinese" title="Wu Chinese">Wu Chinese</a> pronunciations of <span class="t_nihongo_kanji"><span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span></span> and was introduced to European languages through early trade.<sup id="cite_ref-Mancall_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mancall-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the 13th century, <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo" title="Marco Polo">Marco Polo</a> recorded the <a href="/wiki/Early_Mandarin" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Mandarin">Early Mandarin</a> Chinese pronunciation of the characters <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh"></span></span> as <span title="Mandarin Chinese-language romanization"><i lang="cmn-Latn">Cipangu</i></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The old <a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">Malay</a> name for Japan, <span title="Malay (macrolanguage)-language text"><i lang="ms">Japang</i></span> or <span title="Malay (macrolanguage)-language text"><i lang="ms">Japun</i></span>, was borrowed from a southern coastal Chinese dialect and encountered by <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> traders in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, who brought the word to Europe in the early 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The first version of the name in English appears in a book published in 1577, which spelled the name as <i>Giapan</i> in a translation of a 1565 Portuguese letter.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mancall_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mancall-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="History">History</h2></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Japan" title="History of Japan">History of Japan</a></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Japanese_history" title="Timeline of Japanese history">Timeline of Japanese history</a>.</div>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Prehistoric_to_classical_history">Prehistoric to classical history</h3></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Emperor_Jimmu.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Emperor_Jimmu.jpg/170px-Emperor_Jimmu.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="247" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Emperor_Jimmu.jpg/255px-Emperor_Jimmu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Emperor_Jimmu.jpg/340px-Emperor_Jimmu.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1242" data-file-height="1807"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Legend" title="Legend">Legendary</a> <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Jimmu" title="Emperor Jimmu">Emperor Jimmu</a><span style="font-weight: normal"> (<span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span>, <span title="Hepburn transliteration"><i lang="ja-Latn">Jinmu-tenn</i></span>)</span></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Modern humans arrived in Japan around 38,000 years ago (~36,000 BC), marking the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Paleolithic" title="Japanese Paleolithic">Japanese Paleolithic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This was followed from around 14,500&nbsp;BC (the start of the <a href="/wiki/J%C5%8Dmon_period" title="Jmon period">Jmon period</a>) by a <a href="/wiki/Mesolithic" title="Mesolithic">Mesolithic</a> to <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> semi-sedentary <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherer</a> culture characterized by <a href="/wiki/Pit-house" title="Pit-house">pit dwelling</a> and rudimentary agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/J%C5%8Dmon_pottery" title="Jmon pottery">Clay vessels</a> from the period are among the oldest surviving examples of pottery.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Japonic_languages" title="Japonic languages">Japonic</a>-speaking <a href="/wiki/Yayoi_people" title="Yayoi people">Yayoi people</a> entered the archipelago from the Korean Peninsula,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Yayoi_culture_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yayoi_culture-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> intermingling with the <a href="/wiki/J%C5%8Dmon_people" title="Jmon people">Jmon</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-Yayoi_culture_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yayoi_culture-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Yayoi_period" title="Yayoi period">Yayoi period</a> saw the introduction of practices including <a href="/wiki/Paddy_field" title="Paddy field">wet-rice farming</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> a new <a href="/wiki/Yayoi_pottery" title="Yayoi pottery">style of pottery</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and metallurgy from China and Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to legend, <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Jimmu" title="Emperor Jimmu">Emperor Jimmu</a> (descendant of <a href="/wiki/Amaterasu" title="Amaterasu">Amaterasu</a>) founded <a href="/wiki/Yamatai" title="Yamatai">a kingdom</a> in central Japan in 660 BC, beginning <a href="/wiki/Imperial_House_of_Japan" title="Imperial House of Japan">a continuous imperial line</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan first appears in written history in the Chinese <i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Han" title="Book of Han">Book of Han</a></i>, completed in 111 AD. <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> was introduced to Japan from <a href="/wiki/Baekje" title="Baekje">Baekje</a> (a Korean kingdom) in 552, but the development of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">Japanese Buddhism</a> was primarily influenced by China.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite early resistance, Buddhism was promoted by the ruling class, including figures like <a href="/wiki/Prince_Sh%C5%8Dtoku" title="Prince Shtoku">Prince Shtoku</a>, and gained widespread acceptance beginning in the <a href="/wiki/Asuka_period" title="Asuka period">Asuka period</a> (592710).<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>In 645, the government led by <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Tenji" title="Emperor Tenji">Prince Naka no e</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fujiwara_no_Kamatari" title="Fujiwara no Kamatari">Fujiwara no Kamatari</a> devised and implemented the far-reaching <a href="/wiki/Taika_Reform" title="Taika Reform">Taika Reforms</a>. The Reform began with land reform, based on Confucian ideas and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_philosophy" title="Chinese philosophy">philosophies</a> from <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Totman_2005_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Totman_2005-29"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It nationalized all land in Japan, to be <a href="/wiki/Equal-field_system" title="Equal-field system">distributed equally</a> among cultivators, and ordered the compilation of a household registry as the basis for a new system of taxation.<sup id="cite_ref-Sansom_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sansom-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The true aim of the reforms was to bring about greater centralization and to enhance the power of the imperial court, which was also based on the governmental structure of China. Envoys and students were dispatched to China to learn about Chinese writing, politics, art, and religion.<sup id="cite_ref-Totman_2005_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Totman_2005-29"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jinshin_War" title="Jinshin War">Jinshin War</a> of 672, a bloody conflict between <a href="/wiki/Prince_%C5%8Cama" class="mw-redirect" title="Prince ama">Prince ama</a> and his nephew <a href="/wiki/Prince_%C5%8Ctomo" class="mw-redirect" title="Prince tomo">Prince tomo</a>, became a major catalyst for further administrative reforms.<sup id="cite_ref-ritsuryo_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ritsuryo-31"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> These reforms culminated with the promulgation of the <a href="/wiki/Taih%C5%8D_Code" title="Taih Code">Taih Code</a>, which consolidated existing statutes and established the structure of the central and subordinate local governments.<sup id="cite_ref-Sansom_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sansom-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> These legal reforms created the <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Ritsury%C5%8D" title="Ritsury">ritsury</a></i></span> state, a system of Chinese-style centralized government that remained in place for half a millennium.<sup id="cite_ref-ritsuryo_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ritsuryo-31"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Nara_period" title="Nara period">Nara period</a> (710784) marked the emergence of a Japanese state centered on the Imperial Court in <a href="/wiki/Heij%C5%8D_Palace" title="Heij Palace">Heij-ky</a> (modern <a href="/wiki/Nara,_Nara" class="mw-redirect" title="Nara, Nara">Nara</a>). The period is characterized by the appearance of a nascent <a href="/wiki/Japanese_literature" title="Japanese literature">literary culture</a> with the completion of the <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Kojiki" title="Kojiki">Kojiki</a></i></span> (712) and <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Nihon_Shoki" title="Nihon Shoki">Nihon Shoki</a></i></span> (720), as well as the development of Buddhist-inspired artwork and <a href="/wiki/Historic_Monuments_of_Ancient_Nara" title="Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara">architecture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Courtiers_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Courtiers-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/735%E2%80%93737_Japanese_smallpox_epidemic" title="735737 Japanese smallpox epidemic">smallpox epidemic in 735737</a> is believed to have killed as much as one-third of Japan's population.<sup id="cite_ref-Courtiers_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Courtiers-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 784, <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Kanmu" title="Emperor Kanmu">Emperor Kanmu</a> moved the capital, settling on <a href="/wiki/Heian-ky%C5%8D" title="Heian-ky">Heian-ky</a> (modern-day <a href="/wiki/Kyoto" title="Kyoto">Kyoto</a>) in 794.<sup id="cite_ref-Courtiers_33-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Courtiers-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This marked the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Heian_period" title="Heian period">Heian period</a> (7941185), during which a distinctly indigenous Japanese culture emerged. <a href="/wiki/Murasaki_Shikibu" title="Murasaki Shikibu">Murasaki Shikibu</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Genji" title="The Tale of Genji">The Tale of Genji</a></i> and the lyrics of Japan's national anthem <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">"<a href="/wiki/Kimigayo" title="Kimigayo">Kimigayo</a>"</i></span> were written during this time.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Feudal_era">Feudal era</h3></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Mokoshuraiekotoba.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Mokoshuraiekotoba.jpg/220px-Mokoshuraiekotoba.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="107" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Mokoshuraiekotoba.jpg/330px-Mokoshuraiekotoba.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Mokoshuraiekotoba.jpg/440px-Mokoshuraiekotoba.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2112" data-file-height="1024"></a><figcaption>Japanese <a href="/wiki/Samurai" title="Samurai">samurai</a> boarding a Mongol vessel during the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Japan" title="Mongol invasions of Japan">Mongol invasions of Japan</a>, depicted in the <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/M%C5%8Dko_Sh%C5%ABrai_Ekotoba" title="Mko Shrai Ekotoba">Mko Shrai Ekotoba</a></i></span>, 1293</figcaption></figure>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Three_Unifiers_of_Japan.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/The_Three_Unifiers_of_Japan.jpg/220px-The_Three_Unifiers_of_Japan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/The_Three_Unifiers_of_Japan.jpg/330px-The_Three_Unifiers_of_Japan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/The_Three_Unifiers_of_Japan.jpg/440px-The_Three_Unifiers_of_Japan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="748" data-file-height="500"></a><figcaption>Three unifiers of Japan. Left to right: <a href="/wiki/Oda_Nobunaga" title="Oda Nobunaga">Oda Nobunaga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toyotomi_Hideyoshi" title="Toyotomi Hideyoshi">Toyotomi Hideyoshi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_Ieyasu" title="Tokugawa Ieyasu">Tokugawa Ieyasu</a>.</figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan's feudal era was characterized by the emergence and dominance of a ruling class of warriors, the <a href="/wiki/Samurai" title="Samurai">samurai</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Leibo2015_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Leibo2015-36"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 1185, following the defeat of the <a href="/wiki/Taira_clan" title="Taira clan">Taira clan</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Minamoto_clan" title="Minamoto clan">Minamoto clan</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Genpei_War" title="Genpei War">Genpei War</a>, samurai <a href="/wiki/Minamoto_no_Yoritomo" title="Minamoto no Yoritomo">Minamoto no Yoritomo</a> established a <a href="/wiki/Military_government" title="Military government">military government</a> at <a href="/wiki/Kamakura" title="Kamakura">Kamakura</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After Yoritomo's death, the <a href="/wiki/H%C5%8Dj%C5%8D_clan" title="Hj clan">Hj clan</a> came to power as regents for the <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">shgun</i></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-Courtiers_33-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Courtiers-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a> school of Buddhism was introduced from China in the <a href="/wiki/Kamakura_period" title="Kamakura period">Kamakura period</a> (11851333) and became popular among the samurai class.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kamakura_shogunate" title="Kamakura shogunate">Kamakura shogunate</a> repelled <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Japan" title="Mongol invasions of Japan">Mongol invasions</a> in 1274 and 1281 but was eventually <a href="/wiki/Kenmu_Restoration" title="Kenmu Restoration">overthrown</a> by <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Go-Daigo" title="Emperor Go-Daigo">Emperor Go-Daigo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Courtiers_33-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Courtiers-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Go-Daigo was defeated by <a href="/wiki/Ashikaga_Takauji" title="Ashikaga Takauji">Ashikaga Takauji</a> in 1336, beginning the <a href="/wiki/Muromachi_period" title="Muromachi period">Muromachi period</a> (13361573).<sup id="cite_ref-Shirane2012a_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shirane2012a-39"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The succeeding <a href="/wiki/Ashikaga_shogunate" title="Ashikaga shogunate">Ashikaga shogunate</a> failed to control the feudal warlords (<span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">daimy</i></span>) and a <a href="/wiki/%C5%8Cnin_War" title="nin War">civil war began in 1467</a>, opening the century-long <a href="/wiki/Sengoku_period" title="Sengoku period">Sengoku period</a> ("Warring States").<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>During the 16th century, Portuguese traders and <a href="/wiki/Jesuit" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesuit">Jesuit</a> missionaries reached Japan for the first time, initiating direct <a href="/wiki/Nanban_trade" title="Nanban trade">commercial</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nanban_art" title="Nanban art">cultural</a> exchange between Japan and the West.<sup id="cite_ref-Courtiers_33-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Courtiers-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Oda_Nobunaga" title="Oda Nobunaga">Oda Nobunaga</a> used European technology and firearms to conquer many other <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">daimy</i></span>;<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> his consolidation of power began what was known as the <a href="/wiki/Azuchi%E2%80%93Momoyama_period" title="AzuchiMomoyama period">AzuchiMomoyama period</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After <a href="/wiki/Honn%C5%8D-ji_Incident" title="Honn-ji Incident">the death of Nobunaga</a> in 1582, his successor, <a href="/wiki/Toyotomi_Hideyoshi" title="Toyotomi Hideyoshi">Toyotomi Hideyoshi</a>, unified the nation in the early 1590s and launched <a href="/wiki/Japanese_invasions_of_Korea_(1592%E2%80%9398)" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese invasions of Korea (159298)">two unsuccessful invasions of Korea in 1592 and 1597</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Courtiers_33-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Courtiers-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p><a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_Ieyasu" title="Tokugawa Ieyasu">Tokugawa Ieyasu</a> served as <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Five_Elders" title="Council of Five Elders">regent</a> for Hideyoshi's son <a href="/wiki/Toyotomi_Hideyori" title="Toyotomi Hideyori">Toyotomi Hideyori</a> and used his position to gain political and military support.<sup id="cite_ref-Turnbull2011_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Turnbull2011-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> When open war broke out, Ieyasu defeated rival clans in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sekigahara" title="Battle of Sekigahara">Battle of Sekigahara</a> in 1600. He was appointed <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">shgun</i></span> by <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Go-Y%C5%8Dzei" title="Emperor Go-Yzei">Emperor Go-Yzei</a> in 1603 and established the <a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_shogunate" title="Tokugawa shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a> at <a href="/wiki/Edo" title="Edo">Edo</a> (modern Tokyo).<sup id="cite_ref-Closed_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Closed-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The shogunate enacted measures including <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Buke_shohatto" title="Buke shohatto">buke shohatto</a></i></span>, as a code of conduct to control the autonomous <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">daimy</i></span>,<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and in 1639 the isolationist <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Sakoku" title="Sakoku">sakoku</a></i></span> ("closed country") policy that spanned the two and a half centuries of tenuous political unity known as the <a href="/wiki/Edo_period" title="Edo period">Edo period</a> (16031868).<sup id="cite_ref-Closed_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Closed-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Modern Japan's economic growth began in this period, resulting in <a href="/wiki/Kaid%C5%8D" title="Kaid">roads</a> and water transportation routes, as well as financial instruments such as <a href="/wiki/Futures_contract" title="Futures contract">futures contracts</a>, banking and insurance of the <a href="/wiki/Osaka_rice_brokers" class="mw-redirect" title="Osaka rice brokers">Osaka rice brokers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The study of Western sciences (<span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Rangaku" title="Rangaku">rangaku</a></i></span>) continued through contact with the Dutch enclave in <a href="/wiki/Nagasaki" title="Nagasaki">Nagasaki</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Closed_45-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Closed-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Edo period gave rise to <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Kokugaku" title="Kokugaku">kokugaku</a></i></span> ("national studies"), the study of Japan by the Japanese.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Modern_era">Modern era</h3></div>
    <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1237032888/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}@media screen{html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner img{background-color:white}}@media screen and (prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner img{background-color:white}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:312px;max-width:312px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:130px;max-width:130px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:175px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Meiji_tenno1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Meiji_tenno1.jpg/128px-Meiji_tenno1.jpg" decoding="async" width="128" height="175" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Meiji_tenno1.jpg/192px-Meiji_tenno1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Meiji_tenno1.jpg/256px-Meiji_tenno1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="879" data-file-height="1203"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Emperor_Meiji" title="Emperor Meiji">Emperor Meiji</a><span style="font-weight: normal"> (<span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span>, <span title="Hepburn transliteration"><i lang="ja-Latn">Meiji-tenn</i></span>)</span>; 18521912</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:178px;max-width:178px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:175px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Japanese_Empire_(orthographic_projection).svg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Japanese_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/176px-Japanese_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="176" height="176" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Japanese_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/264px-Japanese_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Japanese_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/352px-Japanese_Empire_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="600"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese Empire">Japanese Empire</a> and its influence, 1942</div></div></div></div></div>
    <p>The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy" title="United States Navy">United States Navy</a> sent Commodore <a href="/wiki/Matthew_C._Perry" title="Matthew C. Perry">Matthew C. Perry</a> to force the opening of Japan to the outside world. Arriving at <a href="/wiki/Uraga,_Kanagawa" title="Uraga, Kanagawa">Uraga</a> with four "<a href="/wiki/Black_Ships" title="Black Ships">Black Ships</a>" in July 1853, the <a href="/wiki/Perry_Expedition" title="Perry Expedition">Perry Expedition</a> resulted in the March 1854 <a href="/wiki/Convention_of_Kanagawa" title="Convention of Kanagawa">Convention of Kanagawa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Closed_45-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Closed-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Subsequent similar treaties with other Western countries brought economic and political crises.<sup id="cite_ref-Closed_45-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Closed-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The resignation of the <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">shgun</i></span> led to the <a href="/wiki/Boshin_War" title="Boshin War">Boshin War</a> and the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_han_system" title="Abolition of the han system">centralized state</a> nominally unified under the emperor (the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Restoration" title="Meiji Restoration">Meiji Restoration</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Adopting Western political, judicial, and military institutions, the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Japan" title="Cabinet of Japan">Cabinet</a> organized the <a href="/wiki/Privy_Council_(Japan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Privy Council (Japan)">Privy Council</a>, introduced the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Constitution" title="Meiji Constitution">Meiji Constitution</a> (November 29, 1890), and assembled the <a href="/wiki/National_Diet" title="National Diet">Imperial Diet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-modernnation_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-modernnation-51"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_period" class="mw-redirect" title="Meiji period">Meiji period</a> (18681912), the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a> emerged as the most developed state in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> and as an industrialized world power that pursued military conflict to expand its sphere of influence.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After victories in the <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> (18941895) and the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War" title="Russo-Japanese War">Russo-Japanese War</a> (19041905), Japan gained control of Taiwan, Korea and the southern half of <a href="/wiki/Sakhalin" title="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-modernnation_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-modernnation-51"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and annexed Korea in 1910.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Japanese population doubled from 35 million in 1873 to 70 million by 1935, with a significant shift to urbanization.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-excesses_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-excesses-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The early 20th century saw a period of <a href="/wiki/Taish%C5%8D_period" class="mw-redirect" title="Taish period">Taish democracy</a> (19121926) overshadowed by increasing <a href="/wiki/Expansionism" title="Expansionism">expansionism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_militarism" title="Japanese militarism">militarization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ramesh_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ramesh-60"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japan_during_World_War_I" title="Japan during World War I">World War I</a> allowed Japan, which joined the side of the victorious <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a>, to capture <a href="/wiki/German_colonial_empire" title="German colonial empire">German possessions</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Pacific" class="mw-redirect" title="Pacific">Pacific</a> and China in <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">1920</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ramesh_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ramesh-60"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The 1920s saw a political shift towards <a href="/wiki/Statism_in_Sh%C5%8Dwa_Japan" title="Statism in Shwa Japan">statism</a>, a period of lawlessness following the 1923 <a href="/wiki/Great_Tokyo_Earthquake" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Tokyo Earthquake">Great Tokyo Earthquake</a>, the passing of <a href="/wiki/Peace_Preservation_Law" title="Peace Preservation Law">laws against political dissent</a>, and a series of <a href="/wiki/May_15_Incident" class="mw-redirect" title="May 15 Incident">attempted coups</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-excesses_58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-excesses-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This process accelerated during the 1930s, spawning several radical nationalist groups that shared a hostility to liberal democracy and a dedication to expansion in Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 1931, Japan <a href="/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_Manchuria" title="Japanese invasion of Manchuria">invaded China and occupied Manchuria</a>, which led to the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Puppet_state" title="Puppet state">puppet state</a> of <a href="/wiki/Manchukuo" title="Manchukuo">Manchukuo</a> in 1932; following <a href="/wiki/Lytton_Report" title="Lytton Report">international condemnation of the occupation</a>, it resigned from the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> in 1933.<sup id="cite_ref-Inc1945_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Inc1945-64"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 1936, Japan signed the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Comintern_Pact" title="Anti-Comintern Pact">Anti-Comintern Pact</a> with <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>; the 1940 <a href="/wiki/Tripartite_Pact" title="Tripartite Pact">Tripartite Pact</a> made it one of the <a href="/wiki/Axis_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Axis Powers">Axis Powers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-excesses_58-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-excesses-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Mamoru_Shigemitsu_signs_the_Instrument_of_Surrender,_officially_ending_the_Second_World_War.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Mamoru_Shigemitsu_signs_the_Instrument_of_Surrender%2C_officially_ending_the_Second_World_War.jpg/220px-Mamoru_Shigemitsu_signs_the_Instrument_of_Surrender%2C_officially_ending_the_Second_World_War.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Mamoru_Shigemitsu_signs_the_Instrument_of_Surrender%2C_officially_ending_the_Second_World_War.jpg/330px-Mamoru_Shigemitsu_signs_the_Instrument_of_Surrender%2C_officially_ending_the_Second_World_War.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Mamoru_Shigemitsu_signs_the_Instrument_of_Surrender%2C_officially_ending_the_Second_World_War.jpg/440px-Mamoru_Shigemitsu_signs_the_Instrument_of_Surrender%2C_officially_ending_the_Second_World_War.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5738" data-file-height="4594"></a><figcaption>Japan's imperial ambitions ended on September 2, 1945, with the country's surrender to the Allies.</figcaption></figure>
    <p>The Empire of Japan invaded other parts of China in 1937, precipitating the <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a> (19371945).<sup id="cite_ref-Paine2012_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Paine2012-65"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 1940, the Empire <a href="/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_French_Indochina" title="Japanese invasion of French Indochina">invaded French Indochina</a>, after which the United States placed an oil embargo on Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-excesses_58-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-excesses-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On December 78, 1941, Japanese forces carried out surprise <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attacks on Pearl Harbor</a>, as well as on British forces in <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Malaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Malaya">Malaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bombing_of_Singapore_(1941)" title="Bombing of Singapore (1941)">Singapore</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hong_Kong" title="Battle of Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, among others, beginning <a href="/wiki/Pacific_War" title="Pacific War">World War II in the Pacific</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Throughout areas occupied by Japan during the war, numerous abuses were committed against local inhabitants, with many forced into <a href="/wiki/Comfort_women" title="Comfort women">sexual slavery</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied</a> victories during the next four years, which culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria" title="Soviet invasion of Manchuria">Soviet invasion of Manchuria</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki">atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki</a> in 1945, Japan agreed to <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">an unconditional surrender</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The war cost Japan millions of lives and <a href="/wiki/Territorial_conquests_of_the_Empire_of_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Territorial conquests of the Empire of Japan">its colonies</a>, including <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> parts of Japan such as <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_under_Japanese_rule" title="Taiwan under Japanese rule">Taiwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karafuto_Prefecture" title="Karafuto Prefecture">Karafuto</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands" title="Kuril Islands">Kurils</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-excesses_58-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-excesses-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Allies (led by the United States) repatriated millions of <a href="/wiki/Japanese_diaspora" title="Japanese diaspora">Japanese settlers</a> from their former colonies and military camps throughout Asia, largely eliminating the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese Empire">Japanese Empire</a> and its influence over the territories it conquered.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-phoenix_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phoenix-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Allies convened the <a href="/wiki/International_Military_Tribunal_for_the_Far_East" title="International Military Tribunal for the Far East">International Military Tribunal for the Far East</a> to prosecute Japanese leaders except the Emperor<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> for <a href="/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes" title="Japanese war crimes">war crimes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-phoenix_71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phoenix-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>In 1947, Japan adopted <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">a new constitution</a> emphasizing liberal democratic practices.<sup id="cite_ref-phoenix_71-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phoenix-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Japan" title="Occupation of Japan">Allied occupation</a> ended with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco" title="Treaty of San Francisco">Treaty of San Francisco</a> in 1952,<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and Japan was granted membership in the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> in 1956.<sup id="cite_ref-phoenix_71-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phoenix-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Japanese_economic_miracle" title="Japanese economic miracle">period of record growth</a> propelled Japan to become the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_largest_historical_GDP" title="List of countries by largest historical GDP">second-largest economy</a> in the world;<sup id="cite_ref-phoenix_71-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phoenix-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> this ended in the mid-1990s after the popping of an <a href="/wiki/Japanese_asset_price_bubble" title="Japanese asset price bubble">asset price bubble</a>, beginning the "<a href="/wiki/Lost_Decade_(Japan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Lost Decade (Japan)">Lost Decade</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2011, Japan suffered one of the largest earthquakes in its recorded history - the <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 Thoku earthquake and tsunami">Thoku earthquake</a> - triggering the <a href="/wiki/Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster" class="mw-redirect" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes-tsunami_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-tsunami-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On May 1, 2019, after the historic <a href="/wiki/Abdication_of_Emperor_Akihito" class="mw-redirect" title="Abdication of Emperor Akihito">abdication of Emperor Akihito</a>, his son <a href="/wiki/Naruhito" title="Naruhito">Naruhito</a> became Emperor, beginning the <span title="Japanese-language text"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Reiwa" class="mw-redirect" title="Reiwa">Reiwa</a></i></span> era.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Geography">Geography</h2></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Japan" title="Geography of Japan">Geography of Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Japan" title="Geology of Japan">Geology of Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Japan_topo_en.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Japan_topo_en.jpg/260px-Japan_topo_en.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="278" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Japan_topo_en.jpg/390px-Japan_topo_en.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Japan_topo_en.jpg/520px-Japan_topo_en.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="1498"></a><figcaption>A topographic map of Japan</figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan comprises <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Japan" title="List of islands of Japan">14,125 islands</a> extending along the Pacific coast of Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It stretches over 3000&nbsp;km (1900&nbsp;mi) northeastsouthwest from the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Okhotsk" title="Sea of Okhotsk">Sea of Okhotsk</a> to the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-water_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-water-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country's five main islands, from north to south, are <a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">Hokkaido</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honshu" title="Honshu">Honshu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shikoku" title="Shikoku">Shikoku</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyushu" title="Kyushu">Kyushu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Okinawa_Island" title="Okinawa Island">Okinawa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands" title="Ryukyu Islands">Ryukyu Islands</a>, which include Okinawa, are a chain to the south of Kyushu. The <a href="/wiki/Nanp%C5%8D_Islands" title="Nanp Islands">Nanp Islands</a> are south and east of the main islands of Japan. Together they are often known as the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_archipelago" title="Japanese archipelago">Japanese archipelago</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Japan's territory is 377,975.24&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (145,937.06&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-area-2019_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-area-2019-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_length_of_coastline" title="List of countries by length of coastline">sixth-longest coastline</a> in the world at 29,751&nbsp;km (18,486&nbsp;mi). Because of its far-flung outlying islands, <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone_of_Japan" title="Exclusive economic zone of Japan">Japan's exclusive economic zone</a> is the eighth-largest in the world, covering 4,470,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,730,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-cia_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The Japanese archipelago is 67% <a href="/wiki/Forestry_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Forestry in Japan">forests</a> and 14% <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Agriculture in Japan">agricultural</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The primarily rugged and mountainous terrain is restricted for habitation.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Thus the habitable zones, mainly in the coastal areas, have very high population densities: Japan is the 40th <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population_density" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population density">most densely populated country</a> even without considering that local concentration.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Honshu has the highest population density at 450 persons/km<sup>2</sup> (1200/sq mi) as of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, while Hokkaido has the lowest density of 64.5 persons/km<sup>2</sup> as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-JPCensus_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JPCensus-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, approximately 0.5% of Japan's total area is <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">reclaimed land</a> (<span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">umetatechi</i></span>).<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lake_Biwa" title="Lake Biwa">Lake Biwa</a> is an <a href="/wiki/Ancient_lake" title="Ancient lake">ancient lake</a> and the country's largest freshwater lake.<sup id="cite_ref-Tabata2016_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabata2016-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan is substantially prone to <a href="/wiki/Earthquakes_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Earthquakes in Japan">earthquakes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tsunami" title="Tsunami">tsunami</a> and <a href="/wiki/Types_of_volcanic_eruptions" title="Types of volcanic eruptions">volcanic eruptions</a> because of its location along the Pacific Ring of Fire.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_disaster_risk" title="List of countries by natural disaster risk">17th highest natural disaster risk</a> as measured in the 2016 World Risk Index.<sup id="cite_ref-wri_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wri-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has 111 active volcanoes.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Destructive earthquakes, often resulting in tsunami, occur several times each century;<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/1923_Great_Kant%C5%8D_earthquake" title="1923 Great Kant earthquake">1923 Tokyo earthquake</a> killed over 140,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> More recent major quakes are the 1995 <a href="/wiki/Great_Hanshin_earthquake" title="Great Hanshin earthquake">Great Hanshin earthquake</a> and the 2011 Thoku earthquake, which triggered a large tsunami.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes-tsunami_75-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-tsunami-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Climate">Climate</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Japan#Climate" title="Geography of Japan">Geography of Japan &nbsp;Climate</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Chuurei-tou_Fujiyoshida_17025277650_c59733d6ba_o.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Chuurei-tou_Fujiyoshida_17025277650_c59733d6ba_o.jpg/220px-Chuurei-tou_Fujiyoshida_17025277650_c59733d6ba_o.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Chuurei-tou_Fujiyoshida_17025277650_c59733d6ba_o.jpg/330px-Chuurei-tou_Fujiyoshida_17025277650_c59733d6ba_o.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Chuurei-tou_Fujiyoshida_17025277650_c59733d6ba_o.jpg/440px-Chuurei-tou_Fujiyoshida_17025277650_c59733d6ba_o.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5004" data-file-height="3336"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Mount_Fuji" title="Mount Fuji">Mount Fuji</a> in Spring, view from <a href="/wiki/Arakurayama_Sengen_Park" title="Arakurayama Sengen Park">Arakurayama Sengen Park</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>The climate of Japan is predominantly temperate but varies greatly from north to south. The northernmost region, Hokkaido, has a <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a> with long, cold winters and very warm to cool summers. <a href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">Precipitation</a> is not heavy, but the islands usually develop deep snowbanks in the winter.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a> region on Honshu's west coast, northwest winter winds bring heavy snowfall during winter. In the summer, the region sometimes experiences extremely hot temperatures because of the <a href="/wiki/Foehn_wind" title="Foehn wind">Foehn</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Central_Highland_(Japan)" title="Central Highland (Japan)">Central Highland</a> has a typical inland humid continental climate, with large temperature differences between summer and winter. The mountains of the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C5%ABgoku_region" title="Chgoku region">Chgoku</a> and Shikoku regions shelter the <a href="/wiki/Seto_Inland_Sea" title="Seto Inland Sea">Seto Inland Sea</a> from seasonal winds, bringing mild weather year-round.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The Pacific coast features a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical" class="mw-redirect" title="Humid subtropical">humid subtropical</a> climate that experiences milder winters with occasional snowfall and hot, humid summers because of the southeast seasonal wind. The Ryukyu and Nanp Islands have a <a href="/wiki/Subtropics" title="Subtropics">subtropical climate</a>, with warm winters and hot summers. Precipitation is very heavy, especially during the rainy season.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_96-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The main <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_rainy_season" title="East Asian rainy season">rainy season</a> begins in early May in Okinawa, and the rain front gradually moves north. In late summer and early autumn, <a href="/wiki/Typhoon" title="Typhoon">typhoons</a> often bring heavy rain.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to the Environment Ministry, heavy rainfall and increasing temperatures have caused problems in the agricultural industry and elsewhere.<sup id="cite_ref-climatechange_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climatechange-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The highest temperature ever measured in Japan, 41.1&nbsp;C (106.0&nbsp;F), was recorded on July 23, 2018,<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and repeated on August 17, 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Japan" title="Wildlife of Japan">Wildlife of Japan</a></div>
