    <p>Japan has nine forest <a href="/wiki/Ecoregions_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Ecoregions in Japan">ecoregions</a> which reflect the climate and geography of the islands. They range from <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forests" title="Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests">subtropical moist broadleaf forests</a> in the Ryky and <a href="/wiki/Bonin_Islands" title="Bonin Islands">Bonin Islands</a>, to <a href="/wiki/Temperate_broadleaf_and_mixed_forests" title="Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests">temperate broadleaf and mixed forests</a> in the mild climate regions of the main islands, to <a href="/wiki/Temperate_coniferous_forest" title="Temperate coniferous forest">temperate coniferous forests</a> in the cold, winter portions of the northern islands.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has over 90,000 species of wildlife as of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup id="cite_ref-Sakurai2019_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sakurai2019-103"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> including the <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">brown bear</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_macaque" title="Japanese macaque">Japanese macaque</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_raccoon_dog" title="Japanese raccoon dog">Japanese raccoon dog</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Small_Japanese_field_mouse" title="Small Japanese field mouse">small Japanese field mouse</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_giant_salamander" title="Japanese giant salamander">Japanese giant salamander</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>A large network of <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Japan" title="List of national parks of Japan">national parks</a> has been established to protect important areas of flora and fauna as well as 52 <a href="/wiki/Ramsar_sites_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Ramsar sites in Japan">Ramsar wetland sites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage Sites in Japan">Four sites</a> have been inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List for their outstanding natural value.<sup id="cite_ref-unesco1_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unesco1-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Environment">Environment</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Japan" title="Environmental issues in Japan">Environmental issues in Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Japan" title="Climate change in Japan">Climate change in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Kongobuji_Koyasan07n3200.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Kongobuji_Koyasan07n3200.jpg/220px-Kongobuji_Koyasan07n3200.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Kongobuji_Koyasan07n3200.jpg/330px-Kongobuji_Koyasan07n3200.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Kongobuji_Koyasan07n3200.jpg/440px-Kongobuji_Koyasan07n3200.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="2133"></a><figcaption>Autumn <a href="/wiki/Maple_tree" class="mw-redirect" title="Maple tree">maple leaves</a> (<span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Momiji" class="mw-redirect" title="Momiji">momiji</a></i></span>) at <a href="/wiki/Kong%C5%8Dbu-ji" title="Kongbu-ji">Kongbu-ji</a> on <a href="/wiki/Mount_K%C5%8Dya" title="Mount Kya">Mount Kya</a>, a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>In the period of rapid economic growth after World War II, environmental policies were downplayed by the government and industrial corporations; as a result, <a href="/wiki/Four_Big_Pollution_Diseases_of_Japan" title="Four Big Pollution Diseases of Japan">environmental pollution</a> was widespread in the 1950s and 1960s. Responding to rising concerns, the government introduced environmental protection laws in 1970.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">oil crisis in 1973</a> also encouraged the efficient use of energy because of Japan's lack of natural resources.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan ranks 20th in the 2018 <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index" title="Environmental Performance Index">Environmental Performance Index</a>, which measures a country's commitment to environmental sustainability.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions" title="List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions">fifth-largest emitter</a> of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-climatechange_99-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climatechange-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As the host and signatory of the 1997 <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol</a>, Japan is under treaty obligation to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions and to take other steps to curb climate change.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2020, the government of Japan announced a target of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_neutrality" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon neutrality">carbon-neutrality</a> by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Environmental issues include urban air pollution (<a href="/wiki/NOx" title="NOx">NOx</a>, suspended <a href="/wiki/Particulate_matter" class="mw-redirect" title="Particulate matter">particulate matter</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Toxics" class="mw-redirect" title="Toxics">toxics</a>), <a href="/wiki/Waste_management" title="Waste management">waste management</a>, water <a href="/wiki/Eutrophication" title="Eutrophication">eutrophication</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nature_conservation" title="Nature conservation">nature conservation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Japan" title="Climate change in Japan">climate change</a>, chemical management and international co-operation for conservation.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</h2></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Japan" title="Emperor of Japan">Emperor of Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Japan" title="Government of Japan">Government of Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Japan" title="Politics of Japan">Politics of Japan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Japan" title="Law of Japan">Law of Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_cropped_Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_20191110_1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_cropped_Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_20191110_1.jpg/220px-Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_cropped_Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_20191110_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="131" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_cropped_Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_20191110_1.jpg/330px-Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_cropped_Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_20191110_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_cropped_Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_20191110_1.jpg/440px-Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_cropped_Emperor_Naruhito_and_Empress_Masako_20191110_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="879" data-file-height="522"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Emperor_Naruhito" class="mw-redirect" title="Emperor Naruhito">Emperor Naruhito</a>, current head of state, and <a href="/wiki/Empress_Masako" title="Empress Masako">Empress Masako</a> participated in the <a href="https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E7%A5%9D%E8%B3%80%E5%BE%A1%E5%88%97%E3%81%AE%E5%84%80" class="extiw" title="ja:">Imperial Procession by motorcar after the Ceremony of the Enthronement</a> in <a href="/wiki/T%C5%8Dky%C5%8D_Metropolis" class="mw-redirect" title="Tky Metropolis">Tokyo</a> on November 10, 2019.</figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> in which the power of the <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Japan" title="Emperor of Japan">Emperor</a> is limited to a <a href="/wiki/Ceremonial_head_of_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Ceremonial head of state">ceremonial role</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-euparl_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euparl-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Executive power is instead wielded by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Japan" title="Prime Minister of Japan">Prime Minister of Japan</a> and his <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Japan" title="Cabinet of Japan">Cabinet</a>, whose sovereignty is vested in the Japanese people.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitution_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Naruhito" title="Naruhito">Naruhito</a> is the Emperor of Japan, having succeeded his father <a href="/wiki/Akihito" title="Akihito">Akihito</a> upon his accession to the <a href="/wiki/Chrysanthemum_Throne" title="Chrysanthemum Throne">Chrysanthemum Throne</a> in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-euparl_114-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euparl-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Diet_of_Japan_Kokkai_2009.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Diet_of_Japan_Kokkai_2009.jpg/220px-Diet_of_Japan_Kokkai_2009.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Diet_of_Japan_Kokkai_2009.jpg/330px-Diet_of_Japan_Kokkai_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Diet_of_Japan_Kokkai_2009.jpg/440px-Diet_of_Japan_Kokkai_2009.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2561" data-file-height="1726"></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/National_Diet_Building" title="National Diet Building">National Diet Building</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan's legislative organ is the <a href="/wiki/National_Diet" title="National Diet">National Diet</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliament" title="Parliament">parliament</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-euparl_114-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euparl-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It consists of a lower <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_(Japan)" title="House of Representatives (Japan)">House of Representatives</a> with 465 seats, elected by popular vote every four years or when dissolved, and an upper <a href="/wiki/House_of_Councillors" title="House of Councillors">House of Councillors</a> with 245 seats, whose popularly-elected members serve six-year terms.<sup id="cite_ref-sec_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sec-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> There is <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a> for adults over 18 years of age,<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with a <a href="/wiki/Secret_ballot" title="Secret ballot">secret ballot</a> for all elected offices.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitution_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The prime minister as the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> has the power to appoint and dismiss <a href="/wiki/Ministers_of_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministers of State">Ministers of State</a>, and is <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Investiture" title="Imperial Investiture">appointed</a> by the emperor after being designated from among the members of the Diet.<sup id="cite_ref-sec_116-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sec-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fumio_Kishida" title="Fumio Kishida">Fumio Kishida</a> is Japan's prime minister; he took office after winning the <a href="/wiki/2021_Liberal_Democratic_Party_(Japan)_leadership_election" class="mw-redirect" title="2021 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election">2021 Liberal Democratic Party leadership election</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_politics" title="Right-wing politics">right-wing</a> <a href="/wiki/Big_tent" title="Big tent">big tent</a> <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Democratic_Party_(Japan)" title="Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)">Liberal Democratic Party</a> has been the <a href="/wiki/Dominant-party_system" title="Dominant-party system">dominant party</a> in the country since the 1950s, often called the <a href="/wiki/1955_System" title="1955 System">1955 System</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Historically influenced by <a href="/wiki/Chinese_law" title="Chinese law">Chinese law</a>, the Japanese legal system developed independently during the Edo period through texts such as <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Kujikata_Osadamegaki" title="Kujikata Osadamegaki">Kujikata Osadamegaki</a></i></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-dean_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dean-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since the late 19th century, <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Japan" title="Judicial system of Japan">the judicial system</a> has been largely based on the <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> of Europe, notably Germany. In 1896, Japan established a <a href="/wiki/Civil_code" title="Civil code">civil code</a> based on the German <a href="/wiki/B%C3%BCrgerliches_Gesetzbuch" title="Brgerliches Gesetzbuch">Brgerliches Gesetzbuch</a>, which remains in effect with postWorld War II modifications.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">Constitution of Japan</a>, adopted in 1947, is the oldest unamended constitution in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-anomalous-constitution_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-anomalous-constitution-122"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Statutory law originates in the legislature, and the constitution requires that the emperor promulgate legislation passed by the Diet without giving him the power to oppose legislation. The main body of Japanese statutory law is called the <a href="/wiki/Six_Codes" title="Six Codes">Six Codes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-dean_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dean-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan's court system is divided into four basic tiers: the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Japan" title="Supreme Court of Japan">Supreme Court</a> and three levels of lower courts.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Japan" title="Administrative divisions of Japan">Administrative divisions of Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prefectures_of_Japan" title="Prefectures of Japan">Prefectures of Japan</a></div>
    <p>Japan is divided into 47 prefectures, each overseen by an elected <a href="/wiki/Governor_(Japan)" title="Governor (Japan)">governor</a> and legislature.<sup id="cite_ref-euparl_114-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euparl-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the following table, the prefectures are grouped by <a href="/wiki/List_of_regions_of_Japan" title="List of regions of Japan">region</a>:<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <table>
    <tbody><tr>
    <td rowspan="2"><figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Regions_and_Prefectures_of_Japan_2.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Regions_and_Prefectures_of_Japan_2.svg/290px-Regions_and_Prefectures_of_Japan_2.svg.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="384" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Regions_and_Prefectures_of_Japan_2.svg/435px-Regions_and_Prefectures_of_Japan_2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Regions_and_Prefectures_of_Japan_2.svg/580px-Regions_and_Prefectures_of_Japan_2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="570" data-file-height="755"></a><figcaption>Prefectures of Japan with colored regions</figcaption></figure>
    </td>
    <td style="padding-right:1em; padding-left:2em; vertical-align:top;">
