    <div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Japan" title="Foreign relations of Japan">Foreign relations of Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:G7_in_het_Catshuis.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/G7_in_het_Catshuis.jpg/260px-G7_in_het_Catshuis.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="173" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/G7_in_het_Catshuis.jpg/390px-G7_in_het_Catshuis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/G7_in_het_Catshuis.jpg/520px-G7_in_het_Catshuis.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3861" data-file-height="2574"></a><figcaption>Japan is a member of both the <a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a> and the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>.</figcaption></figure>
    <p>A member state of the United Nations since 1956, Japan is one of the <a href="/wiki/G4_nations" title="G4 nations">G4 countries</a> seeking reform of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">Security Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan is a member of the <a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>, and "<a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Free_Trade_Area#ASEAN_Plus_Three" title="ASEAN Free Trade Area">ASEAN Plus Three</a>", and is a participant in the <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">East Asia Summit</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-terada_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-terada-126"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It is the world's fifth-largest donor of <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a>, donating US$9.2 billion in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2024, Japan had the fourth-largest diplomatic network in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan has close economic and military relations with the United States, with which it maintains a <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Mutual_Cooperation_and_Security_between_the_United_States_and_Japan" title="Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security between the United States and Japan">security alliance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-us-relations_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-us-relations-129"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The United States is a major market for Japanese exports and a major source of Japanese imports, and is committed to defending the country, with military bases in Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-us-relations_129-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-us-relations-129"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2016, Japan announced the Free and Open Indo-Pacific vision, which frames its regional policies.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/Quadrilateral_Security_Dialogue" title="Quadrilateral Security Dialogue">Quadrilateral Security Dialogue</a> ("the Quad"), a multilateral security dialogue reformed in 2017 aiming to limit Chinese influence in the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pacific" title="Indo-Pacific">Indo-Pacific</a> region, along with the United States, Australia, and India.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
    </p><p>Japan is engaged in several territorial disputes with its neighbors. Japan contests Russia's control of the <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands_dispute" title="Kuril Islands dispute">Southern Kuril Islands</a>, which were occupied by the Soviet Union in 1945.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> South Korea's control of the <a href="/wiki/Liancourt_Rocks" title="Liancourt Rocks">Liancourt Rocks</a> is acknowledged but not accepted as they are claimed by Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-takeshima_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-takeshima-135"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has strained relations with China and Taiwan over the <a href="/wiki/Senkaku_Islands" title="Senkaku Islands">Senkaku Islands</a> and the status of <a href="/wiki/Okinotorishima" title="Okinotorishima">Okinotorishima</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Military">Military</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Japan_Self-Defense_Forces" title="Japan Self-Defense Forces">Japan Self-Defense Forces</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_051115-N-8492C-125_The_Japan_Maritime_Self-Defense_Force_(JMSDF)_destroyer_JDS_Kongou_(DDG_173)_sails_in_formation_with_other_JMSDF_ships_and_ships_assigned_to_the_USS_Kitty_Hawk_Carrier_Strike_Group.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/US_Navy_051115-N-8492C-125_The_Japan_Maritime_Self-Defense_Force_%28JMSDF%29_destroyer_JDS_Kongou_%28DDG_173%29_sails_in_formation_with_other_JMSDF_ships_and_ships_assigned_to_the_USS_Kitty_Hawk_Carrier_Strike_Group.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/US_Navy_051115-N-8492C-125_The_Japan_Maritime_Self-Defense_Force_%28JMSDF%29_destroyer_JDS_Kongou_%28DDG_173%29_sails_in_formation_with_other_JMSDF_ships_and_ships_assigned_to_the_USS_Kitty_Hawk_Carrier_Strike_Group.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/US_Navy_051115-N-8492C-125_The_Japan_Maritime_Self-Defense_Force_%28JMSDF%29_destroyer_JDS_Kongou_%28DDG_173%29_sails_in_formation_with_other_JMSDF_ships_and_ships_assigned_to_the_USS_Kitty_Hawk_Carrier_Strike_Group.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Japan_Maritime_Self-Defense_Force" title="Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force">JMSDF</a> <a href="/wiki/Kong%C5%8D-class_destroyer" title="Kong-class destroyer"><span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">Kong</i></span>-class destroyer</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan is the third highest-ranked Asian country in the 2024 <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">Global Peace Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It spent 1.1% of its total GDP on <a href="/wiki/Military_budget_of_Japan" title="Military budget of Japan">its defence budget</a> in 2022,<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and maintained the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by military expenditures">tenth-largest military budget</a> in the world in 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-SIPRI-2020_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SIPRI-2020-139"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country's military (the Japan Self-Defense Forces) is restricted by <a href="/wiki/Article_9_of_the_Japanese_Constitution" title="Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution">Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution</a>, which renounces Japan's right to declare war or use military force in international disputes.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The military is governed by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Japan)" title="Ministry of Defense (Japan)">Ministry of Defense</a>, and primarily consists of the <a href="/wiki/Japan_Ground_Self-Defense_Force" title="Japan Ground Self-Defense Force">Japan Ground Self-Defense Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Japan_Maritime_Self-Defense_Force" title="Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force">Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Japan_Air_Self-Defense_Force" title="Japan Air Self-Defense Force">Japan Air Self-Defense Force</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Iraq_Reconstruction_and_Support_Group" title="Japanese Iraq Reconstruction and Support Group">deployment of troops to Iraq</a> and Afghanistan marked the first overseas use of Japan's military since World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Japan" title="Government of Japan">Government of Japan</a> has been making changes to its security policy which include the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Council_(Japan)" title="National Security Council (Japan)">National Security Council</a>, the adoption of the National Security Strategy, and the development of the National Defense Program Guidelines.<sup id="cite_ref-Japan's_Security_Policy_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Japan's_Security_Policy-142"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In May 2014, Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Shinzo_Abe" title="Shinzo Abe">Shinzo Abe</a> said Japan wanted to shed the passiveness it has maintained since the end of World War II and take more responsibility for regional security.<sup id="cite_ref-JapanAsia_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JapanAsia-143"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In December 2022, Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Fumio_Kishida" title="Fumio Kishida">Fumio Kishida</a> further confirmed this trend, instructing the government to increase spending by 65% until 2027.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Recent tensions, particularly with North Korea and China, have reignited the debate over the status of the JSDF and its relation to Japanese society.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Law_enforcement">Law enforcement</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Japan" title="Law enforcement in Japan">Law enforcement in Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Japan" title="Crime in Japan">Crime in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%E8%AD%A6%E8%A6%96%E5%BA%81_-_panoramio.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/%E8%AD%A6%E8%A6%96%E5%BA%81_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-%E8%AD%A6%E8%A6%96%E5%BA%81_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/%E8%AD%A6%E8%A6%96%E5%BA%81_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-%E8%AD%A6%E8%A6%96%E5%BA%81_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/%E8%AD%A6%E8%A6%96%E5%BA%81_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-%E8%AD%A6%E8%A6%96%E5%BA%81_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456"></a><figcaption>The headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Metropolitan_Police_Department" title="Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department">Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Domestic security in Japan is provided mainly by the <a href="/wiki/Prefectural_police_department" class="mw-redirect" title="Prefectural police department">prefectural police departments</a>, under the oversight of the <a href="/wiki/National_Police_Agency_(Japan)" title="National Police Agency (Japan)">National Police Agency</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As the central coordinating body for the Prefectural Police Departments, the National Police Agency is administered by the <a href="/wiki/National_Public_Safety_Commission_(Japan)" title="National Public Safety Commission (Japan)">National Public Safety Commission</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NPA1977-2_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NPA1977-2-148"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Special_Assault_Team" title="Special Assault Team">Special Assault Team</a> comprises national-level <a href="/wiki/Counter-terrorism" class="mw-redirect" title="Counter-terrorism">counter-terrorism</a> tactical units that cooperate with territorial-level <a href="/wiki/Riot_Police_Unit#Specialist_squads" title="Riot Police Unit">Anti-Firearms Squads and Counter-NBC Terrorism Squads</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WP_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WP-149"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Japan_Coast_Guard" title="Japan Coast Guard">Japan Coast Guard</a> guards territorial waters surrounding Japan and uses surveillance and control countermeasures against smuggling, marine <a href="/wiki/Environmental_crime" title="Environmental crime">environmental crime</a>, poaching, piracy, spy ships, unauthorized foreign fishing vessels, and illegal immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Firearm_and_Sword_Possession_Control_Law" title="Firearm and Sword Possession Control Law">Firearm and Sword Possession Control Law</a> strictly regulates the civilian ownership of guns, swords, and other weaponry.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Office_on_Drugs_and_Crime" title="United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime">United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime</a>, among the member states of the UN that report statistics as of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the incidence rates of violent crimes such as murder, abduction, sexual violence, and robbery are very low in Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Human_rights">Human rights</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Japan" title="Human rights in Japan">Human rights in Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Japan" title="LGBT rights in Japan">LGBT rights in Japan</a></div>
    <p>Japan has faced criticism for <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Same-sex marriage in Japan">not allowing same-sex marriages</a>, despite a majority of Japanese people supporting marriage equality.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It is the least developed out of the <a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a> countries in terms of LGBT equality.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan legally prohibits racial and religious discrimination under <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">its constitution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan is also a signatory to the <a href="/wiki/International_Convention_on_the_Elimination_of_All_Forms_of_Racial_Discrimination" title="International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination">International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while facing criticism for <a href="/wiki/Racial_profiling" title="Racial profiling">racial profiling</a> by police.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan is among the few developed countries which still legally retain and actively <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Japan" title="Capital punishment in Japan">allow capital punishment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Economy">Economy</h2></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Japan" title="Economy of Japan">Economy of Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Nakanoshima_Skyscrapers_in_201504_001.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Nakanoshima_Skyscrapers_in_201504_001.jpg/220px-Nakanoshima_Skyscrapers_in_201504_001.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Nakanoshima_Skyscrapers_in_201504_001.jpg/330px-Nakanoshima_Skyscrapers_in_201504_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Nakanoshima_Skyscrapers_in_201504_001.jpg/440px-Nakanoshima_Skyscrapers_in_201504_001.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3840" data-file-height="2400"></a><figcaption>Skyscrapers in <a href="/wiki/Nakanoshima" title="Nakanoshima">Nakanoshima</a>, <a href="/wiki/Osaka" title="Osaka">Osaka</a>; a major <a href="/wiki/Financial_center" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial center">financial center</a> in Japan</figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">fourth-largest economy by nominal GDP</a>, after that of the United States, China and Germany; and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">fourth-largest economy</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, <a href="/wiki/Labor_market_of_Japan" title="Labor market of Japan">Japan's labor force</a> is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_labour_force" title="List of countries by labour force">eighth-largest</a>, consisting of over 68.6 million workers.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_82-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Japan has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_unemployment_rate" title="List of countries by unemployment rate">low unemployment rate</a> of around 2.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Japan" title="Poverty in Japan">Its poverty rate</a> is the second highest among the G7 countries,<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and exceeds 15.7% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has the highest ratio of <a href="/wiki/National_debt_of_Japan" title="National debt of Japan">public debt</a> to GDP among advanced economies,<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with national debt estimated at 248% relative to GDP as of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>169<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Japanese_yen" title="Japanese yen">Japanese yen</a> is the world's third-largest <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">reserve currency</a> after the US dollar and the euro.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan was the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">fifth-largest exporter</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports" title="List of countries by imports">fourth-largest importer</a> in 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Its exports amounted to 18.2% of its total GDP in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Japan's main export markets were China (23.9 percent, including Hong Kong) and the United States (18.5 percent).<sup id="cite_ref-STATJETRO_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STATJETRO-175"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Its main exports are motor vehicles, iron and steel products, semiconductors, and auto parts.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_82-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan's main import markets as of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> were China (21.1 percent), the United States (9.9 percent), and Australia (9.8 percent).<sup id="cite_ref-STATJETRO_175-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STATJETRO-175"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan's main imports are machinery and equipment, fossil fuels, foodstuffs, chemicals, and raw materials for its industries.<sup id="cite_ref-STATJETRO_175-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STATJETRO-175"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The Japanese variant of capitalism has many distinct features: <a href="/wiki/Keiretsu" title="Keiretsu">keiretsu</a> enterprises are influential, and <a href="/wiki/Lifetime_employment" class="mw-redirect" title="Lifetime employment">lifetime employment</a> and seniority-based career advancement are common in the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_work_environment" title="Japanese work environment">Japanese work environment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-oecd2008_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oecd2008-176"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has a large <a href="/wiki/Cooperative" title="Cooperative">cooperative</a> sector, with three of the world's ten largest cooperatives, including the largest <a href="/wiki/Consumer_cooperative" class="mw-redirect" title="Consumer cooperative">consumer cooperative</a> and the largest <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_cooperative" title="Agricultural cooperative">agricultural cooperative</a> as of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It <a href="/wiki/International_rankings_of_Japan#Economy" title="International rankings of Japan">ranks highly</a> for <a href="/wiki/Competition_(companies)" class="mw-redirect" title="Competition (companies)">competitiveness</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economic_freedom" title="Economic freedom">economic freedom</a>. Japan ranked sixth in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report" title="Global Competitiveness Report">Global Competitiveness Report</a> in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It attracted 31.9&nbsp;million international tourists in 2019,<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and was <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">ranked eleventh</a> in the world in 2019 for inbound tourism.<sup id="cite_ref-WTOB_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTOB-181"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The 2021 <i><a href="/wiki/Travel_and_Tourism_Competitiveness_Report" title="Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report">Travel and Tourism Competitiveness Report</a></i> ranked Japan first in the world out of 117 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Its international tourism receipts in 2019 amounted to $46.1 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-WTOB_181-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTOB-181"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Agriculture_and_fishery">Agriculture and fishery</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture,_forestry,_and_fishing_in_Japan" title="Agriculture, forestry, and fishing in Japan">Agriculture, forestry, and fishing in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Rice_Paddies_In_Aizu,_Japan.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Rice_Paddies_In_Aizu%2C_Japan.JPG/220px-Rice_Paddies_In_Aizu%2C_Japan.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Rice_Paddies_In_Aizu%2C_Japan.JPG/330px-Rice_Paddies_In_Aizu%2C_Japan.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Rice_Paddies_In_Aizu%2C_Japan.JPG/440px-Rice_Paddies_In_Aizu%2C_Japan.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a><figcaption>A <a href="/wiki/Rice_paddy" class="mw-redirect" title="Rice paddy">rice paddy</a> in <a href="/wiki/Aizu" title="Aizu">Aizu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fukushima_Prefecture" title="Fukushima Prefecture">Fukushima Prefecture</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>The Japanese agricultural sector accounts for about 1.2% of the country's total GDP as of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-sec_116-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sec-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Only 11.5% of Japan's land is suitable for cultivation.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Because of this lack of arable land, a system of <a href="/wiki/Terrace_(earthworks)" title="Terrace (earthworks)">terraces</a> is used to farm in small areas.<sup id="cite_ref-Urbanites_Help_Sustain_Japan's_Historic_Rice_Paddy_Terraces_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Urbanites_Help_Sustain_Japan's_Historic_Rice_Paddy_Terraces-184"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This results in one of the world's highest levels of crop yields per unit area, with an agricultural self-sufficiency rate of about 50% as of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan's small agricultural sector is highly subsidized and <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_Protectionism_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Agricultural Protectionism in Japan">protected</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> There has been a growing concern about farming as farmers are aging with a difficult time finding successors.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan ranked seventh in the world in <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_by_country" title="Fishing industry by country">tonnage of fish caught</a> and captured 3,167,610 metric tons of fish in 2016, down from an annual average of 4,000,000 tons over the previous decade.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan maintains one of the world's largest fishing fleets and accounts for nearly 15% of the global catch,<sup id="cite_ref-cia_82-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> prompting critiques that Japan's fishing is leading to depletion in fish stocks such as <a href="/wiki/Tuna" title="Tuna">tuna</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has sparked controversy by supporting commercial <a href="/wiki/Whaling_in_Japan" title="Whaling in Japan">whaling</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Industry_and_services">Industry and services</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing_in_Japan" title="Manufacturing in Japan">Manufacturing in Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trade_and_services_in_Japan" title="Trade and services in Japan">Trade and services in Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electronics_industry_in_Japan" title="Electronics industry in Japan">Electronics industry in Japan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Japan" title="Automotive industry in Japan">Automotive industry in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:2019-2021_Toyota_RAV4_Hybrid_G_E-Four_2.5_6AA-AXAH54_(20220826).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/2019-2021_Toyota_RAV4_Hybrid_G_E-Four_2.5_6AA-AXAH54_%2820220826%29.jpg/220px-2019-2021_Toyota_RAV4_Hybrid_G_E-Four_2.5_6AA-AXAH54_%2820220826%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="111" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/2019-2021_Toyota_RAV4_Hybrid_G_E-Four_2.5_6AA-AXAH54_%2820220826%29.jpg/330px-2019-2021_Toyota_RAV4_Hybrid_G_E-Four_2.5_6AA-AXAH54_%2820220826%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/2019-2021_Toyota_RAV4_Hybrid_G_E-Four_2.5_6AA-AXAH54_%2820220826%29.jpg/440px-2019-2021_Toyota_RAV4_Hybrid_G_E-Four_2.5_6AA-AXAH54_%2820220826%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4077" data-file-height="2053"></a><figcaption>The "<a href="/wiki/Toyota_RAV4" title="Toyota RAV4">RAV4</a>" manufactured by <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">Toyota</a>. Japan is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_motor_vehicle_production" title="List of countries by motor vehicle production">third-largest maker of motor vehicles</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-191"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan has a large industrial capacity and is home to some of the "largest and most technologically advanced producers of motor vehicles, <a href="/wiki/Machine_tool" title="Machine tool">machine tools</a>, steel and nonferrous metals, ships, <a href="/wiki/Chemical_substance" title="Chemical substance">chemical substances</a>, textiles, and <a href="/wiki/Food_processing" title="Food processing">processed foods</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-cia_82-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan's industrial sector makes up approximately 27.5% of its GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_82-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country's manufacturing output is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_manufacturing_output" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by manufacturing output">fourth highest</a> in the world as of 2023<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan is in the top three globally for both automobile production<sup id="cite_ref-:0_191-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-191"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and export,<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and is home to <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">Toyota</a>, the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_manufacturers_by_motor_vehicle_production" title="List of manufacturers by motor vehicle production">largest automobile company</a> by vehicle production. The Japanese shipbuilding industry faces increasing competition from its East Asian neighbors, South Korea and China; a 2020 government initiative identified this sector as a target for increasing exports.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan's service sector accounts for about 69.5% of its total economic output as of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Banking_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Banking in Japan">Banking</a>, retail, <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Transportation in Japan">transportation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Telecommunications in Japan">telecommunications</a> are all major industries, with companies such as Toyota, <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_UFJ_Financial_Group" title="Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group">Mitsubishi UFJ</a>, -<a href="/wiki/Nippon_Telegraph_and_Telephone" title="Nippon Telegraph and Telephone">NTT</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aeon_(company)" title="Aeon (company)">Aeon</a>, <a href="/wiki/SoftBank_Group" title="SoftBank Group">SoftBank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hitachi" title="Hitachi">Hitachi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Itochu" title="Itochu">Itochu</a> listed as among the largest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Fortune_Global_500_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fortune_Global_500-197"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_Japan" title="History of science and technology in Japan">History of science and technology in Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Japan" title="Science and technology in Japan">Science and technology in Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Video_gaming_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Video gaming in Japan">Video gaming in Japan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Japanese_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Japanese inventions and discoveries">List of Japanese inventions and discoveries</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg/220px-Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg/330px-Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg/440px-Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2039"></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Experiment_Module" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese Experiment Module">Japanese Experiment Module</a> (Kib) at the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Relative to gross domestic product, Japan's <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> budget is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_by_research_and_development_spending" title="List of sovereign states by research and development spending">second highest</a> in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with 867,000 researchers sharing a 19-trillion-yen research and development budget as of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country has produced twenty-two <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel laureates</a> in either physics, chemistry or medicine,<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and three <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields medalists</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan leads the world in <a href="/wiki/Japanese_robotics" title="Japanese robotics">robotics</a> production and use, supplying 45% of the world's 2020 total;<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> down from 55% in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has the second highest number of researchers in science and technology per capita in the world with 14 per 1000 employees.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Once considered the strongest in the world, the Japanese consumer electronics industry is in a state of decline as regional competition arises in neighboring East Asian countries such as South Korea and China.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, <a href="/wiki/Video_games_in_Japan" title="Video games in Japan">Japan's video game sector</a> remains a major industry. In 2014, Japan's consumer video game market grossed $9.6 billion, with $5.8 billion coming from mobile gaming.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By 2015, Japan had become the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_video_games_markets_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="List of video games markets by country">fourth-largest</a> <a href="/wiki/PC_game" title="PC game">PC game</a> market, behind only <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, and <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Japan_Aerospace_Exploration_Agency" class="mw-redirect" title="Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency">Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency</a> is Japan's national <a href="/wiki/Space_agency" class="mw-redirect" title="Space agency">space agency</a>; it conducts space, planetary, and aviation research, and leads development of rockets and satellites.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It is a participant in the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Experiment_Module" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese Experiment Module">Japanese Experiment Module</a> (Kib) was added to the station during <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a> assembly flights in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Space_probe" class="mw-redirect" title="Space probe">space probe</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Akatsuki_(spacecraft)" title="Akatsuki (spacecraft)">Akatsuki</a></i> was launched in 2010 and achieved orbit around Venus in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan's plans in <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a> include building a <a href="/wiki/Colonization_of_the_Moon" title="Colonization of the Moon">Moon base</a> and landing astronauts by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2007, it launched lunar explorer <a href="/wiki/SELENE" title="SELENE">SELENE</a> (Selenological and Engineering Explorer) from <a href="/wiki/Tanegashima_Space_Center" title="Tanegashima Space Center">Tanegashima Space Center</a>. The largest lunar mission since the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_program" title="Apollo program">Apollo program</a>, its purpose was to gather data on the <a href="/wiki/Moon#Formation" title="Moon">Moon's origin and evolution</a>. The explorer entered a lunar orbit on October 4, 2007,<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and was deliberately crashed into the Moon on June 11, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</h2></div>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Transportation">Transportation</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Japan" title="Transport in Japan">Transport in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Japan_Airlines,_Boeing_787-9_JA861J_NRT_(19455285040).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Japan_Airlines%2C_Boeing_787-9_JA861J_NRT_%2819455285040%29.jpg/220px-Japan_Airlines%2C_Boeing_787-9_JA861J_NRT_%2819455285040%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Japan_Airlines%2C_Boeing_787-9_JA861J_NRT_%2819455285040%29.jpg/330px-Japan_Airlines%2C_Boeing_787-9_JA861J_NRT_%2819455285040%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Japan_Airlines%2C_Boeing_787-9_JA861J_NRT_%2819455285040%29.jpg/440px-Japan_Airlines%2C_Boeing_787-9_JA861J_NRT_%2819455285040%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4678" data-file-height="3120"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Japan_Airlines" title="Japan Airlines">Japan Airlines</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a> of Japan</figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan has invested heavily in transportation infrastructure since the 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country has approximately 1,200,000 kilometers (750,000 miles) of roads made up of 1,000,000 kilometers (620,000 miles) of city, town and village roads, 130,000 kilometers (81,000 miles) of prefectural roads, 54,736 kilometers (34,011 miles) of general national highways and 7641 kilometers (4748 miles) of national <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_Japan" title="Expressways of Japan">expressways</a> as of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Since privatization in 1987,<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_railway_companies_in_Japan" title="List of railway companies in Japan">dozens of Japanese railway companies</a> compete in regional and local passenger transportation markets; major companies include seven <a href="/wiki/Japan_Railways_Group" title="Japan Railways Group">JR</a> enterprises, <a href="/wiki/Kintetsu_Railway" title="Kintetsu Railway">Kintetsu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seibu_Railway" title="Seibu Railway">Seibu Railway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Keio_Corporation" title="Keio Corporation">Keio Corporation</a>. The high-speed <a href="/wiki/Shinkansen" title="Shinkansen">Shinkansen</a> (bullet trains) that connect major cities are known for their safety and punctuality.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Japan" title="List of airports in Japan">175 airports in Japan</a> as of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_82-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The largest domestic airport, <a href="/wiki/Haneda_Airport" title="Haneda Airport">Haneda Airport</a> in Tokyo, was Asia's <a href="/wiki/List_of_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="List of busiest airports by passenger traffic">second-busiest airport</a> in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Keihin and Hanshin superport hubs are among the largest in the world, at 7.98 and 5.22 million <a href="/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit" title="Twenty-foot equivalent unit">TEU</a> respectively as of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Energy">Energy</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Japan" title="Energy in Japan">Energy in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Setokazenooka-park01.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Setokazenooka-park01.jpg/220px-Setokazenooka-park01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="184" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Setokazenooka-park01.jpg/330px-Setokazenooka-park01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Setokazenooka-park01.jpg/440px-Setokazenooka-park01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="668"></a><figcaption>Part of the <a href="/wiki/Seto_Windhill" title="Seto Windhill">Seto Hill Windfarm</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 37.1% of energy in Japan was produced from petroleum, 25.1% from coal, 22.4% from natural gas, 3.5% from <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a> and 2.8% from <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Japan" title="Nuclear power in Japan">nuclear power</a>, among other sources. Nuclear power was down from 11.2 percent in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By May 2012 all of the country's nuclear power plants had been taken offline because of ongoing public opposition following the <a href="/wiki/Fukushima_nuclear_disaster" class="mw-redirect" title="Fukushima nuclear disaster">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a> in March 2011, though government officials continued to try to sway public opinion in favor of returning at least some to service.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sendai_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Sendai Nuclear Power Plant">Sendai Nuclear Power Plant</a> restarted in 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and since then several other nuclear power plants have been restarted.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan lacks significant domestic reserves and has a heavy dependence on <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_imports" title="List of countries by oil imports">imported energy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country has therefore aimed to diversify its sources and maintain high levels of energy efficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Japan" title="Water supply and sanitation in Japan">Water supply and sanitation in Japan</a></div>
    <p>Responsibility for the water and sanitation sector is shared between the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health,_Labour_and_Welfare_(Japan)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (Japan)">Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare</a>, in charge of water supply for domestic use; the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Land,_Infrastructure,_Transport_and_Tourism" title="Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism">Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism</a>, in charge of water resources development as well as sanitation; the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Environment_(Japan)" title="Ministry of the Environment (Japan)">Ministry of the Environment</a>, in charge of ambient water quality and environmental preservation; and the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Internal_Affairs_and_Communications" title="Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications">Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications</a>, in charge of performance benchmarking of utilities.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Access to an <a href="/wiki/Improved_water_source" title="Improved water source">improved water source</a> is universal in Japan. About 98% of the population receives piped water supply from public utilities.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Demographics">Demographics</h2></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Japan" title="Demographics of Japan">Demographics of Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese people</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Japan" title="Ethnic groups of Japan">Ethnic groups of Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Japan" title="List of metropolitan areas in Japan">List of metropolitan areas in Japan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Japan" title="List of cities in Japan">List of cities in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Tokyo_from_the_top_of_the_SkyTree.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Tokyo_from_the_top_of_the_SkyTree.JPG/260px-Tokyo_from_the_top_of_the_SkyTree.JPG" decoding="async" width="260" height="156" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Tokyo_from_the_top_of_the_SkyTree.JPG/390px-Tokyo_from_the_top_of_the_SkyTree.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Tokyo_from_the_top_of_the_SkyTree.JPG/520px-Tokyo_from_the_top_of_the_SkyTree.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5999" data-file-height="3598"></a><figcaption>View of Tokyo from the top of the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Skytree" title="Tokyo Skytree">Tokyo Skytree</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Greater_Tokyo_Area" title="Greater Tokyo Area">Greater Tokyo Area</a> is ranked as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of metropolitan areas by population">most populous metropolitan area</a> in the world.</figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan has a population of almost 125 million, of whom nearly 122 million are Japanese nationals (2022 estimates).<sup id="cite_ref-November_2020_population_estimate_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-November_2020_population_estimate-230"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A small population of foreign residents makes up the remainder.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
    Japan is the world's <a href="/wiki/Aging_of_Japan" title="Aging of Japan">fastest aging country</a> and has the highest proportion of <a href="/wiki/Elderly_people_in_Japan" title="Elderly people in Japan">elderly citizens</a> of any country, comprising one-third of its total population;<sup id="cite_ref-EUAgeing_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUAgeing-232"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> this is the result of a <a href="/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_baby_boom" class="mw-redirect" title="PostWorld War II baby boom">postWorld War II baby boom</a>, which was followed by an increase in life expectancy and a decrease in <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rates</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has a <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> of 1.4, which is below the <a href="/wiki/Sub-replacement_fertility" title="Sub-replacement fertility">replacement rate</a> of 2.1, and is among the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_fertility_rate" title="List of countries by total fertility rate">lowest</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> it has a <a href="/wiki/Median_age" class="mw-redirect" title="Median age">median age</a> of 48.4, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_median_age" title="List of countries by median age">highest</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-IMFAgeing_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFAgeing-235"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, over 28.7 percent of the population is over 65, or more than one in four out of the Japanese population.<sup id="cite_ref-EUAgeing_232-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUAgeing-232"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As a growing number of younger Japanese are not marrying or remaining childless,<sup id="cite_ref-Walia_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walia-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan's population is expected to drop to around 88 million by 2065.<sup id="cite_ref-EUAgeing_232-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUAgeing-232"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The changes in demographic structure have created several social issues, particularly a decline in the workforce population and an increase in the cost of social security benefits.<sup id="cite_ref-Walia_236-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walia-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Government of Japan projects that there will be almost one elderly person for each person of working age by 2060.<sup id="cite_ref-IMFAgeing_235-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFAgeing-235"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Japan" title="Immigration to Japan">Immigration</a> and birth incentives are sometimes suggested as a solution to provide younger workers to support the nation's aging population.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On April 1, 2019, Japan's revised immigration law was enacted, protecting the rights of foreign workers to help reduce labor shortages in certain sectors.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>In 2022, 92% of the total Japanese population lived in cities.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The capital city, Tokyo, has a population of 13.9 million (2022).<sup id="cite_ref-toukei-metro_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-toukei-metro-242"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It is part of the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Tokyo_Area" title="Greater Tokyo Area">Greater Tokyo Area</a>, the biggest <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of metropolitan areas by population">metropolitan area</a> in the world with 38,140,000 people (2016).<sup id="cite_ref-UN_Worlds_Cities_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Worlds_Cities-243"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan is an ethnically and culturally <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_ranked_by_ethnic_and_cultural_diversity_level" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries ranked by ethnic and cultural diversity level">homogeneous society</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese people</a> forming 98.1% of the country's population.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Minority ethnic groups in the country include the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Ainu_people" title="Ainu people">Ainu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ryukyuan_people" title="Ryukyuan people">Ryukyuan people</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Koreans_in_Japan" title="Koreans in Japan">Zainichi Koreans</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people_in_Japan" title="Chinese people in Japan">Chinese</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Filipinos_in_Japan" title="Filipinos in Japan">Filipinos</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Brazilians mostly <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Brazilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese Brazilian">of Japanese descent</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and Peruvians mostly <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Peruvian" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese Peruvian">of Japanese descent</a> are also among Japan's small minority groups.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Burakumin" title="Burakumin">Burakumin</a></i> make up a social minority group.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1219497266">.mw-parser-output .largestCities-table-background{background:#f9f9f9;color:#222}.mw-parser-output .largestCities-cell-background{background:#f0f0f0;color:#222}</style>
    <div>
