    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Languages">Languages</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Japan" title="Languages of Japan">Languages of Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%E8%B1%9A%E9%AA%A8%E3%82%89%E3%83%BC%E3%82%81%E3%82%93_%E5%8D%9A%E5%A4%9A%E5%A4%A9%E7%A5%9E_%E3%81%84%E3%82%89%E3%81%A3%E3%81%97%E3%82%83%E3%81%84_2010_(5023366778).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/%E8%B1%9A%E9%AA%A8%E3%82%89%E3%83%BC%E3%82%81%E3%82%93_%E5%8D%9A%E5%A4%9A%E5%A4%A9%E7%A5%9E_%E3%81%84%E3%82%89%E3%81%A3%E3%81%97%E3%82%83%E3%81%84_2010_%285023366778%29.jpg/220px-%E8%B1%9A%E9%AA%A8%E3%82%89%E3%83%BC%E3%82%81%E3%82%93_%E5%8D%9A%E5%A4%9A%E5%A4%A9%E7%A5%9E_%E3%81%84%E3%82%89%E3%81%A3%E3%81%97%E3%82%83%E3%81%84_2010_%285023366778%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/%E8%B1%9A%E9%AA%A8%E3%82%89%E3%83%BC%E3%82%81%E3%82%93_%E5%8D%9A%E5%A4%9A%E5%A4%A9%E7%A5%9E_%E3%81%84%E3%82%89%E3%81%A3%E3%81%97%E3%82%83%E3%81%84_2010_%285023366778%29.jpg/330px-%E8%B1%9A%E9%AA%A8%E3%82%89%E3%83%BC%E3%82%81%E3%82%93_%E5%8D%9A%E5%A4%9A%E5%A4%A9%E7%A5%9E_%E3%81%84%E3%82%89%E3%81%A3%E3%81%97%E3%82%83%E3%81%84_2010_%285023366778%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/%E8%B1%9A%E9%AA%A8%E3%82%89%E3%83%BC%E3%82%81%E3%82%93_%E5%8D%9A%E5%A4%9A%E5%A4%A9%E7%A5%9E_%E3%81%84%E3%82%89%E3%81%A3%E3%81%97%E3%82%83%E3%81%84_2010_%285023366778%29.jpg/440px-%E8%B1%9A%E9%AA%A8%E3%82%89%E3%83%BC%E3%82%81%E3%82%93_%E5%8D%9A%E5%A4%9A%E5%A4%A9%E7%A5%9E_%E3%81%84%E3%82%89%E3%81%A3%E3%81%97%E3%82%83%E3%81%84_2010_%285023366778%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5616" data-file-height="3744"></a><figcaption><i><a href="/wiki/Kanji" title="Kanji">Kanji</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Hiragana" title="Hiragana">hiragana</a></i> signs</figcaption></figure>
    <p>The <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese language</a> is Japan's <i>de facto</i> national language and the primary written and spoken language of most people in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-LangPolicy_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LangPolicy-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japanese_writing_system" title="Japanese writing system">Japanese writing</a> uses <a href="/wiki/Kanji" title="Kanji">kanji</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_character" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese character">Chinese characters</a>) and two sets of <a href="/wiki/Kana" title="Kana">kana</a> (<a href="/wiki/Syllabary" title="Syllabary">syllabaries</a> based on <a href="/wiki/Cursive_script_(East_Asia)" title="Cursive script (East Asia)">cursive script</a> and <a href="/wiki/Radical_(Chinese_characters)" class="mw-redirect" title="Radical (Chinese characters)">radicals</a> used by kanji), as well as the <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">Latin alphabet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabic_numerals" title="Arabic numerals">Arabic numerals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> English has taken a major role in Japan as a business and international link language. As a result, the prevalence of English in the educational system has increased, with English classes becoming mandatory at all levels of the Japanese school system by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-LangPolicy_253-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LangPolicy-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Sign_Language" title="Japanese Sign Language">Japanese Sign Language</a> is the primary <a href="/wiki/Sign_language" title="Sign language">sign language</a> used in Japan and has gained some official recognition, but its usage has been historically hindered by discriminatory policies and a lack of educational support.<sup id="cite_ref-LangPolicy_253-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LangPolicy-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Besides Japanese, the <a href="/wiki/Ryukyuan_languages" title="Ryukyuan languages">Ryukyuan languages</a> (<a href="/wiki/Amami_%C5%8Cshima_language" title="Amami shima language">Amami</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kunigami_language" title="Kunigami language">Kunigami</a>, <a href="/wiki/Okinawan_language" title="Okinawan language">Okinawan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miyakoan_language" title="Miyakoan language">Miyako</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yaeyama_language" title="Yaeyama language">Yaeyama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yonaguni_language" title="Yonaguni language">Yonaguni</a>), part of the <a href="/wiki/Japonic_languages" title="Japonic languages">Japonic language family</a>, are spoken in the Ryukyu Islands chain.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Few children learn these languages,<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but local governments have sought to increase awareness of the traditional languages.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ainu_language" title="Ainu language">Ainu language</a>, which is a <a href="/wiki/Language_isolate" title="Language isolate">language isolate</a>, is <a href="/wiki/Moribund_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Moribund language">moribund</a>, with only a few native speakers remaining as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Additionally, a number of other languages are taught and used by ethnic minorities, immigrant communities, and a growing number of foreign-language students, such as <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a> (including a distinct <a href="/wiki/Zainichi_Korean_language" title="Zainichi Korean language">Zainichi Korean dialect</a>), <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-LangPolicy_253-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LangPolicy-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Religion">Religion</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Japan" title="Religion in Japan">Religion in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Itsukushima_Shrine_Torii_Gate_(13890465459).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Itsukushima_Shrine_Torii_Gate_%2813890465459%29.jpg/220px-Itsukushima_Shrine_Torii_Gate_%2813890465459%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Itsukushima_Shrine_Torii_Gate_%2813890465459%29.jpg/330px-Itsukushima_Shrine_Torii_Gate_%2813890465459%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Itsukushima_Shrine_Torii_Gate_%2813890465459%29.jpg/440px-Itsukushima_Shrine_Torii_Gate_%2813890465459%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000"></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Torii" title="Torii">torii</a> of <a href="/wiki/Itsukushima_Shrine" title="Itsukushima Shrine">Itsukushima Shinto Shrine</a> near <a href="/wiki/Hiroshima" title="Hiroshima">Hiroshima</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japan's constitution guarantees full religious freedom.<sup id="cite_ref-Inoue2007_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Inoue2007-259"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Upper estimates suggest that 8496 percent of the Japanese population subscribe to <a href="/wiki/Shinto" title="Shinto">Shinto</a> as its indigenous religion.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, these estimates are based on people <a href="/wiki/Danka_system" title="Danka system">affiliated</a> with a temple, rather than the number of true believers. Many Japanese people practice both Shinto and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">Buddhism</a>; they can identify with both religions or describe themselves as non-religious or spiritual.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The level of participation in religious ceremonies as a cultural tradition remains high, especially during <a href="/wiki/Japanese_festivals" title="Japanese festivals">festivals</a> and occasions such as the <a href="/wiki/Hatsum%C5%8Dde" title="Hatsumde">first shrine visit</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_New_Year" title="Japanese New Year">New Year</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Taoism_in_Japan" title="Taoism in Japan">Taoism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Confucianism_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Confucianism in Japan">Confucianism</a> from China have also influenced Japanese beliefs and customs.<sup id="cite_ref-Totman_2005_29-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Totman_2005-29"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Today, 1%<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> to 1.5% of the population are <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Throughout the latest century, Western customs originally related to Christianity (including <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_Japan" title="Marriage in Japan">Western style weddings</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valentine%27s_Day" title="Valentine's Day">Valentine's Day</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Christmas</a>) have become popular as secular customs among many Japanese.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>About 90% of those practicing <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Japan" title="Islam in Japan">Islam in Japan</a> are foreign-born migrants as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were an estimated 105 <a href="/wiki/Mosque" title="Mosque">mosques</a> and 200,000 Muslims in Japan, 43,000 of which were Japanese nationals.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Other minority religions include <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Japan" title="Hinduism in Japan">Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaism_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Judaism in Japan">Judaism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith_in_Japan" title="Bah Faith in Japan">Bah Faith</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Animist" class="mw-redirect" title="Animist">animist</a> beliefs of the Ainu.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Education">Education</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Japan" title="Education in Japan">Education in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG/220px-Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG/330px-Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG/440px-Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a><figcaption>Students celebrating after the announcement of the results of the <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Japan#University_entrance" title="Higher education in Japan">entrance examinations</a> to the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tokyo" title="University of Tokyo">University of Tokyo</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Since the 1947 <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_Law_of_Education" title="Fundamental Law of Education">Fundamental Law of Education</a>, compulsory education in Japan comprises <a href="/wiki/Elementary_schools_in_Japan" title="Elementary schools in Japan">elementary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Japan#Junior_high_school" title="Secondary education in Japan">junior high school</a>, which together last for nine years.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Almost all children continue their education at a three-year <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Japan" title="Secondary education in Japan">senior high school</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The top-ranking university in the country is the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tokyo" title="University of Tokyo">University of Tokyo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Starting in April 2016, various schools began the academic year with elementary school and junior high school integrated into one nine-year compulsory schooling program; <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education,_Culture,_Sports,_Science_and_Technology" title="Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology">MEXT</a> plans for this approach to be adopted nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> (PISA) coordinated by the OECD ranks the knowledge and skills of Japanese 15-year-olds as the third best in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_Student_performance_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_Student_performance-273"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan is one of the top-performing <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> countries in reading literacy, math, and sciences with the average student scoring 520 and has one of the world's highest-educated labor forces among OECD countries.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-OECD_Student_performance_273-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_Student_performance-273"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It spent 7.4% of its total GDP on education as of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2021, the country ranked third for the percentage of 25 to 64-year-olds that have attained tertiary education with 55.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_GPS_Education_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_GPS_Education-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Approximately 65% of Japanese aged 25 to 34 have some form of tertiary education qualification, with bachelor's degrees being held by 34.2% of Japanese aged 25 to 64, the second most in the OECD after <a href="/wiki/Education_in_South_Korea" title="Education in South Korea">South Korea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_GPS_Education_277-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_GPS_Education-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japanese women are more highly educated than the men: 59 percent of women possess a university degree, compared to 52 percent of men.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Health">Health</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Japan" title="Health in Japan">Health in Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Health_care_system_in_Japan" title="Health care system in Japan">Health care system in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:University_of_Tokyo_Hospital.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/University_of_Tokyo_Hospital.JPG/260px-University_of_Tokyo_Hospital.JPG" decoding="async" width="260" height="195" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/University_of_Tokyo_Hospital.JPG/390px-University_of_Tokyo_Hospital.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/University_of_Tokyo_Hospital.JPG/520px-University_of_Tokyo_Hospital.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/University_of_Tokyo_Hospital" title="University of Tokyo Hospital">University of Tokyo Hospital</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Health care in Japan is provided by national and local governments. Payment for personal medical services is offered through a universal health insurance system that provides relative equality of access, with fees set by a government committee. People without insurance through employers can participate in a national health insurance program administered by local governments.<sup id="cite_ref-Ikegami2014_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ikegami2014-279"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since 1973, all elderly persons have been covered by government-sponsored insurance.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan spent 10.82% of its total GDP on healthcare in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2020, the overall life expectancy in Japan at birth was 85 years (82 years for men and 88 years for women),<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">highest</a> in the world;<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while it had a very low <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality rate</a> (2 per 1,000 <a href="/wiki/Live_birth_(human)" title="Live birth (human)">live births</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since 1981, the principal cause of death in Japan is <a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">cancer</a>, which accounted for 27% of the total deaths in 2018followed by <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">cardiovascular diseases</a>, which led to 15% of the deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has one of the world's <a href="/wiki/Suicide_in_Japan" title="Suicide in Japan">highest suicide rates</a>, which is considered a major social issue.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Another significant public health issue is <a href="/wiki/Smoking_in_Japan" title="Smoking in Japan">smoking among Japanese men</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, Japan has the lowest rate of heart disease in the OECD, and the lowest level of <a href="/wiki/Dementia" title="Dementia">dementia</a> among developed countries.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Culture">Culture</h2></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Japan" title="Culture of Japan">Culture of Japan</a></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Japanese_popular_culture" title="Japanese popular culture">Japanese popular culture</a></div>
    <p>Contemporary Japanese culture combines influences from Asia, Europe, and North America.<sup id="cite_ref-Haffner_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haffner-290"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Traditional Japanese arts include <a href="/wiki/Japanese_handicrafts" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese handicrafts">crafts</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Japanese_pottery_and_porcelain" title="Japanese pottery and porcelain">ceramics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kimono" title="Kimono">textiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_lacquerware" title="Japanese lacquerware">lacquerware</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_sword" title="Japanese sword">swords</a> and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_traditional_dolls" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese traditional dolls">dolls</a>; performances of <a href="/wiki/Bunraku" title="Bunraku">bunraku</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kabuki" title="Kabuki">kabuki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Noh" title="Noh">noh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_traditional_dance" title="Japanese traditional dance">dance</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rakugo" title="Rakugo">rakugo</a>; and other practices, the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_tea_ceremony" title="Japanese tea ceremony">tea ceremony</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ikebana" title="Ikebana">ikebana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_martial_arts" title="Japanese martial arts">martial arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_calligraphy" title="Japanese calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Origami" title="Origami">origami</a>, <a href="/wiki/Onsen" title="Onsen">onsen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geisha" title="Geisha">Geisha</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Japanese_games" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Japanese games">games</a>. Japan has a developed system for the protection and promotion of both tangible and intangible <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Properties_of_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Cultural Properties of Japan">Cultural Properties</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="National Treasures of Japan">National Treasures</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Japan" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Japan">Twenty-two sites</a> have been inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List, eighteen of which are of cultural significance.<sup id="cite_ref-unesco1_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unesco1-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan is considered a <a href="/wiki/Cultural_superpower" class="mw-redirect" title="Cultural superpower">cultural superpower</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Art_and_architecture">Art and architecture</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Japanese_art" title="Japanese art">Japanese art</a></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Japanese_architecture" title="Japanese architecture">Japanese architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_garden" title="Japanese garden">Japanese garden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_esthetics" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese esthetics">Japanese esthetics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_painting" title="Japanese painting">Japanese painting</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_sculpture" title="Japanese sculpture">Japanese sculpture</a></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1237032888/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:312px;max-width:312px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:151px;max-width:151px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:103px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg/149px-The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg" decoding="async" width="149" height="103" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg/224px-The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg/298px-The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4335" data-file-height="2990"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Hokusai" title="Hokusai">Hokusai</a>'s 19th-century <a href="/wiki/Ukiyo-e" title="Ukiyo-e">ukiyo-e</a> <a href="/wiki/Woodblock_printing_in_Japan" title="Woodblock printing in Japan">woodblock print</a> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa" title="The Great Wave off Kanagawa">The Great Wave off Kanagawa</a></i></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:157px;max-width:157px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:103px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:150504_Ritsurin_Park_Takamatsu_Kagawa_pref_Japan01s3.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/150504_Ritsurin_Park_Takamatsu_Kagawa_pref_Japan01s3.jpg/155px-150504_Ritsurin_Park_Takamatsu_Kagawa_pref_Japan01s3.jpg" decoding="async" width="155" height="103" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/150504_Ritsurin_Park_Takamatsu_Kagawa_pref_Japan01s3.jpg/233px-150504_Ritsurin_Park_Takamatsu_Kagawa_pref_Japan01s3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/150504_Ritsurin_Park_Takamatsu_Kagawa_pref_Japan01s3.jpg/310px-150504_Ritsurin_Park_Takamatsu_Kagawa_pref_Japan01s3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Ritsurin_Garden" title="Ritsurin Garden">Ritsurin Garden</a>, one of the most famous strolling gardens in Japan</div></div></div></div></div>
    <p>The history of Japanese painting exhibits synthesis and competition between native Japanese esthetics and imported ideas.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-296"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The interaction between Japanese and European art has been significant: for example <a href="/wiki/Ukiyo-e" title="Ukiyo-e">ukiyo-e</a> prints, which began to be exported in the 19th century in the movement known as <a href="/wiki/Japonism" class="mw-redirect" title="Japonism">Japonism</a>, had a significant influence on the development of modern art in the West, most notably on <a href="/wiki/Post-Impressionism" title="Post-Impressionism">post-Impressionism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_296-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-296"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japanese architecture is a combination of local and other influences. It has traditionally been typified by wooden or mud plaster structures, elevated slightly off the ground, with tiled or thatched roofs.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Minka" title="Minka">Traditional housing</a> and many <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Buddhist_architecture" title="Japanese Buddhist architecture">temple buildings</a> see the use of <a href="/wiki/Tatami" title="Tatami">tatami</a> mats and <a href="/wiki/Sh%C5%8Dji" class="mw-redirect" title="Shji">sliding doors</a> that break down the distinction between rooms and indoor and outdoor space.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since the 19th century, Japan has incorporated much of Western <a href="/wiki/Modern_architecture" title="Modern architecture">modern architecture</a> into construction and design.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It was not until after World War II that Japanese architects made an impression on the international scene, firstly with the work of architects like <a href="/wiki/Kenz%C5%8D_Tange" title="Kenz Tange">Kenz Tange</a> and then with movements like <a href="/wiki/Metabolist_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Metabolist Movement">Metabolism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Literature_and_philosophy">Literature and philosophy</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Japanese_literature" title="Japanese literature">Japanese literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_poetry" title="Japanese poetry">Japanese poetry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_philosophy" title="Japanese philosophy">Japanese philosophy</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg/220px-Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="103" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg/330px-Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg/440px-Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2142" data-file-height="1000"></a><figcaption>12th-century <a href="/wiki/Genji_Monogatari_Emaki" title="Genji Monogatari Emaki">illustrated handscroll</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Genji" title="The Tale of Genji">The Tale of Genji</a></i>, a <a href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="National Treasures of Japan">National Treasure</a></figcaption></figure>
    <p>The earliest works of Japanese literature include the <span title="Japanese-language text"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Kojiki" title="Kojiki">Kojiki</a></i></span> and <span title="Japanese-language text"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Nihon_Shoki" title="Nihon Shoki">Nihon Shoki</a></i></span> chronicles and the <span title="Japanese-language text"><i lang="ja-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Man%27y%C5%8Dsh%C5%AB" title="Man'ysh">Man'ysh</a></i></span> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Japanese_poetry_anthologies" title="List of Japanese poetry anthologies">poetry anthology</a>, all from the 8th century and written in Chinese characters.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the early Heian period, the system of <a href="/wiki/Phonogram_(linguistics)" title="Phonogram (linguistics)">phonograms</a> known as <i>kana</i> (<a href="/wiki/Hiragana" title="Hiragana">hiragana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Katakana" title="Katakana">katakana</a>) was developed.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_the_Bamboo_Cutter" title="The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter">The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter</a></i> is considered the oldest extant Japanese narrative.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> An account of court life is given in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Pillow_Book" title="The Pillow Book">The Pillow Book</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Sei_Sh%C5%8Dnagon" title="Sei Shnagon">Sei Shnagon</a>, while <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Genji" title="The Tale of Genji">The Tale of Genji</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Murasaki_Shikibu" title="Murasaki Shikibu">Murasaki Shikibu</a> is often described as the world's first novel.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>During the Edo period, the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C5%8Dnin" title="Chnin">chnin</a> ("townspeople") overtook the samurai aristocracy as producers and consumers of literature. The popularity of the works of <a href="/wiki/Saikaku" class="mw-redirect" title="Saikaku">Saikaku</a>, for example, reveals this change in readership and authorship, while <a href="/wiki/Matsuo_Bash%C5%8D" title="Matsuo Bash">Bash</a> revivified the poetic tradition of the <a href="/wiki/Kokinsh%C5%AB" class="mw-redirect" title="Kokinsh">Kokinsh</a> with his <a href="/wiki/Haikai" title="Haikai">haikai</a> (<a href="/wiki/Haiku" title="Haiku">haiku</a>) and wrote the poetic travelogue <i><a href="/wiki/Oku_no_Hosomichi" title="Oku no Hosomichi">Oku no Hosomichi</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Meiji era saw the decline of traditional literary forms as Japanese literature integrated Western influences. <a href="/wiki/Natsume_S%C5%8Dseki" title="Natsume Sseki">Natsume Sseki</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mori_%C5%8Cgai" title="Mori gai">Mori gai</a> were significant novelists in the early 20th century, followed by <a href="/wiki/Ry%C5%ABnosuke_Akutagawa" title="Rynosuke Akutagawa">Rynosuke Akutagawa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jun%27ichir%C5%8D_Tanizaki" title="Jun'ichir Tanizaki">Jun'ichir Tanizaki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kaf%C5%AB_Nagai" title="Kaf Nagai">Kaf Nagai</a> and, more recently, <a href="/wiki/Haruki_Murakami" title="Haruki Murakami">Haruki Murakami</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kenji_Nakagami" title="Kenji Nakagami">Kenji Nakagami</a>. Japan has two <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize-winning</a> authors&nbsp; <a href="/wiki/Yasunari_Kawabata" title="Yasunari Kawabata">Yasunari Kawabata</a> (1968) and <a href="/wiki/Kenzabur%C5%8D_%C5%8Ce" title="Kenzabur e">Kenzabur e</a> (1994).<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japanese philosophy has historically been a <a href="/wiki/Information_fusion" class="mw-redirect" title="Information fusion">fusion</a> of both foreign, particularly <a href="/wiki/Chinese_philosophy" title="Chinese philosophy">Chinese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_philosophy" title="Western philosophy">Western</a>, and uniquely Japanese elements. In its literary forms, Japanese philosophy began about fourteen centuries ago. Confucian ideals remain evident in the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_society" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese society">Japanese concept of society</a> and the self, and in the organization of the government and the structure of society.<sup id="cite_ref-Japanese_Confucian_Philosophy_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Japanese_Confucian_Philosophy-309"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Buddhism has profoundly impacted Japanese psychology, metaphysics, and esthetics.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Performing_arts">Performing arts</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Japan" title="Music of Japan">Music of Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Theatre_of_Japan" title="Theatre of Japan">Theatre of Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%E6%98%A5%E6%97%A5%E7%A5%9E%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BC%E7%AF%A0%E5%B1%B1%E3%83%BC%E7%BF%81%E5%A5%89%E7%B4%8DP1011774.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/%E6%98%A5%E6%97%A5%E7%A5%9E%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BC%E7%AF%A0%E5%B1%B1%E3%83%BC%E7%BF%81%E5%A5%89%E7%B4%8DP1011774.jpg/220px-%E6%98%A5%E6%97%A5%E7%A5%9E%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BC%E7%AF%A0%E5%B1%B1%E3%83%BC%E7%BF%81%E5%A5%89%E7%B4%8DP1011774.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/%E6%98%A5%E6%97%A5%E7%A5%9E%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BC%E7%AF%A0%E5%B1%B1%E3%83%BC%E7%BF%81%E5%A5%89%E7%B4%8DP1011774.jpg/330px-%E6%98%A5%E6%97%A5%E7%A5%9E%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BC%E7%AF%A0%E5%B1%B1%E3%83%BC%E7%BF%81%E5%A5%89%E7%B4%8DP1011774.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/%E6%98%A5%E6%97%A5%E7%A5%9E%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BC%E7%AF%A0%E5%B1%B1%E3%83%BC%E7%BF%81%E5%A5%89%E7%B4%8DP1011774.jpg/440px-%E6%98%A5%E6%97%A5%E7%A5%9E%E7%A4%BE%E3%83%BC%E7%AF%A0%E5%B1%B1%E3%83%BC%E7%BF%81%E5%A5%89%E7%B4%8DP1011774.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="960"></a><figcaption><i><a href="/wiki/Noh" title="Noh">Noh</a></i> performance at a Shinto shrine</figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japanese music is eclectic and diverse. Many <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Japanese_musical_instruments" title="Traditional Japanese musical instruments">instruments</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Koto_(instrument)" title="Koto (instrument)">koto</a>, were introduced in the 9th and 10th centuries. The popular <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Japan#Folk_music" title="Music of Japan">folk music</a>, with the guitar-like <a href="/wiki/Shamisen" title="Shamisen">shamisen</a>, dates from the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Western classical music, introduced in the late 19th century, forms an integral part of Japanese culture.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Taiko#Kumi-daiko" title="Taiko">Kumi-daiko</a> (ensemble drumming) was developed in postwar Japan and became very popular in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Popular music in post-war Japan has been heavily influenced by American and European trends, which has led to the evolution of <a href="/wiki/J-pop" title="J-pop">J-pop</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Karaoke" title="Karaoke">Karaoke</a> is a significant cultural activity.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>314<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>The four traditional theaters from Japan are <i><a href="/wiki/Noh" title="Noh">noh</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Ky%C5%8Dgen" title="Kygen">kygen</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Kabuki" title="Kabuki">kabuki</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Bunraku" title="Bunraku">bunraku</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>315<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Noh is one of the oldest continuous theater traditions in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Media">Media</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Japan" title="Cinema of Japan">Cinema of Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manga" title="Manga">Manga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">Anime</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Japan">Media of Japan</a></div>
    <p>According to the 2015 NHK survey on television viewing in Japan, 79 percent of Japanese watch television daily.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>317<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japanese_television_drama" title="Japanese television drama">Japanese television dramas</a> are viewed both within Japan and internationally.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>318<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Many Japanese <a href="/wiki/Media_franchise" title="Media franchise">media franchises</a> have gained considerable global popularity and are among the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_media_franchises" title="List of highest-grossing media franchises">highest-grossing media franchises</a>. <a href="/wiki/Japanese_newspapers" title="Japanese newspapers">Japanese newspapers</a> are among the most circulated in the world as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>319<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan has one of the oldest and largest film industries globally.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ishir%C5%8D_Honda" title="Ishir Honda">Ishir Honda</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Godzilla_(1954_film)" title="Godzilla (1954 film)">Godzilla</a></i> became an international icon of Japan and spawned an entire subgenre of <i><a href="/wiki/Kaiju" title="Kaiju">kaiju</a></i> films, as well as the longest-running film franchise in history.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>321<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japanese comics, known as manga, developed in the mid-20th century and have become popular <a href="/wiki/Manga_outside_Japan" title="Manga outside Japan">worldwide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kinko_Ito_456475_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kinko_Ito_456475-324"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A large number of <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_manga" title="List of best-selling manga">manga series</a> have become some of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_comic_series" title="List of best-selling comic series">best-selling comics series</a> of all time, rivalling the <a href="/wiki/American_comic_book" title="American comic book">American comics industry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japanese animated films and television series, known as anime, were largely influenced by Japanese manga and have become highly popular globally.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>327<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Holidays">Holidays</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Japan" title="Public holidays in Japan">Public holidays in Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_festivals" title="Japanese festivals">Japanese festivals</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg/220px-Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="212" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg/330px-Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg/440px-Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2454" data-file-height="2367"></a><figcaption>Young women celebrate <a href="/wiki/Coming_of_Age_Day" title="Coming of Age Day">Coming of Age Day</a><span style="font-weight: normal"> (<span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span>, <span title="Hepburn transliteration"><i lang="ja-Latn">Seijin no Hi</i></span><span style="margin-left:.09em">)</span></span> in <a href="/wiki/Harajuku" title="Harajuku">Harajuku</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>.</figcaption></figure>
    <p>Officially, Japan has 16 national, government-recognized holidays. Public holidays in Japan are regulated by the Public Holiday Law<span style="font-weight: normal"> (<span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span>, <span title="Hepburn transliteration"><i lang="ja-Latn">Kokumin no Shukujitsu ni Kansuru Hritsu</i></span>)</span> of 1948.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>328<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Beginning in 2000, Japan implemented the <a href="/wiki/Happy_Monday_System" title="Happy Monday System">Happy Monday System</a>, which moved a number of national holidays to Monday in order to obtain a long weekend.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>329<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The national holidays in Japan are <a href="/wiki/Japanese_New_Year" title="Japanese New Year">New Year's Day</a> on January 1, <a href="/wiki/Coming_of_Age_Day" title="Coming of Age Day">Coming of Age Day</a> on the second Monday of January, <a href="/wiki/National_Foundation_Day_(Japan)" title="National Foundation Day (Japan)">National Foundation Day</a> on February 11, <a href="/wiki/The_Emperor%27s_Birthday" title="The Emperor's Birthday">The Emperor's Birthday</a> on February 23, <a href="/wiki/Vernal_Equinox_Day" title="Vernal Equinox Day">Vernal Equinox Day</a> on March 20 or 21, <a href="/wiki/Sh%C5%8Dwa_Day" title="Shwa Day">Shwa Day</a> on April 29, <a href="/wiki/Constitution_Memorial_Day" title="Constitution Memorial Day">Constitution Memorial Day</a> on May 3, <a href="/wiki/Greenery_Day" title="Greenery Day">Greenery Day</a> on May 4, <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_Day_(Japan)" title="Children's Day (Japan)">Children's Day</a> on May 5, <a href="/wiki/Marine_Day" title="Marine Day">Marine Day</a> on the third Monday of July, <a href="/wiki/Mountain_Day" title="Mountain Day">Mountain Day</a> on August 11, <a href="/wiki/Respect_for_the_Aged_Day" title="Respect for the Aged Day">Respect for the Aged Day</a> on the third Monday of September, <a href="/wiki/September_equinox" title="September equinox">Autumnal Equinox</a> on September 23 or 24, <a href="/wiki/Health_and_Sports_Day" class="mw-redirect" title="Health and Sports Day">Health and Sports Day</a> on the second Monday of October, <a href="/wiki/Culture_Day" title="Culture Day">Culture Day</a> on November 3, and <a href="/wiki/Labor_Thanksgiving_Day" title="Labor Thanksgiving Day">Labor Thanksgiving Day</a> on November 23.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>330<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cuisine">Cuisine</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">Japanese cuisine</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:East_West_sushi_01.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/East_West_sushi_01.jpg/220px-East_West_sushi_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/East_West_sushi_01.jpg/330px-East_West_sushi_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/East_West_sushi_01.jpg/440px-East_West_sushi_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6798" data-file-height="4492"></a><figcaption>A plate of <i><a href="/wiki/Sushi" title="Sushi">nigiri-zushi</a></i></figcaption></figure>
    <p>Japanese cuisine offers a vast array of <a href="/wiki/Japanese_regional_cuisine" title="Japanese regional cuisine">regional specialties</a> that use traditional recipes and local ingredients.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>331<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Seafood and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_rice" title="Japanese rice">Japanese rice</a> or <a href="/wiki/Japanese_noodles" title="Japanese noodles">noodles</a> are traditional staples.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>332<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japanese_curry" title="Japanese curry">Japanese curry</a>, since its introduction to Japan from <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British India</a>, is so widely consumed that it can be termed a <a href="/wiki/National_dish" title="National dish">national dish</a>, alongside <a href="/wiki/Ramen" title="Ramen">ramen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sushi" title="Sushi">sushi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>333<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>334<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Traditional Japanese sweets are known as <i>wagashi</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Goldstein2015_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goldstein2015-336"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>335<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Ingredients such as <a href="/wiki/Red_bean_paste" title="Red bean paste">red bean paste</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mochi" title="Mochi">mochi</a> are used. More modern-day tastes include <a href="/wiki/Green_tea_ice_cream" title="Green tea ice cream">green tea ice cream</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FujitaStallings2008_337-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FujitaStallings2008-337"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Popular Japanese beverages include <a href="/wiki/Sake" title="Sake">sake</a>, a brewed rice beverage that typically contains 1417% alcohol and is made by multiple fermentation of rice.<sup id="cite_ref-Batt2014_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Batt2014-338"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Beer has been brewed in Japan since the late 17th century.<sup id="cite_ref-BoultonQuain2013_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoultonQuain2013-339"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>338<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Green_tea" title="Green tea">Green tea</a> is produced in Japan and prepared in forms such as <a href="/wiki/Matcha" title="Matcha">matcha</a>, used in the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_tea_ceremony" title="Japanese tea ceremony">Japanese tea ceremony</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Sports">Sports</h3></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Japan" class="mw-redirect" title="Sport in Japan">Sport in Japan</a></div>
    <figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Aki_basho_dohy%C5%8D-iri_on_Sept._28_2014.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Aki_basho_dohy%C5%8D-iri_on_Sept._28_2014.jpg/220px-Aki_basho_dohy%C5%8D-iri_on_Sept._28_2014.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Aki_basho_dohy%C5%8D-iri_on_Sept._28_2014.jpg/330px-Aki_basho_dohy%C5%8D-iri_on_Sept._28_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Aki_basho_dohy%C5%8D-iri_on_Sept._28_2014.jpg/440px-Aki_basho_dohy%C5%8D-iri_on_Sept._28_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6016" data-file-height="4016"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Sumo" title="Sumo">Sumo</a> wrestlers form around the referee during the ring-entering ceremony.</figcaption></figure>
    <p>Traditionally, <a href="/wiki/Sumo" title="Sumo">sumo</a> is considered Japan's national sport.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>340<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japanese martial arts such as <a href="/wiki/Judo" title="Judo">judo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kendo" title="Kendo">kendo</a> are taught as part of the compulsory junior high school curriculum.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>341<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Baseball_in_Japan" title="Baseball in Japan">Baseball</a> is the most popular sport in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan's top professional league, <a href="/wiki/Nippon_Professional_Baseball" title="Nippon Professional Baseball">Nippon Professional Baseball</a> (NPB), was established in 1936.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>343<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/J.League" title="J.League">Japan Professional Football League</a> (J.League) in 1992, association football gained a wide following.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country co-hosted the <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a> with South Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>345<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan has one of the most successful football teams in Asia, winning the <a href="/wiki/AFC_Asian_Cup" title="AFC Asian Cup">Asian Cup</a> four times,<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/2011_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="2011 FIFA Women's World Cup">FIFA Women's World Cup</a> in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>347<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Golf is also popular in Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Motorsport" title="Motorsport">motorsport</a>, Japanese automotive manufacturers have been successful in multiple different categories, with titles and victories in series such as <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prix_motorcycle_racing" title="Grand Prix motorcycle racing">MotoGP</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Rally_Championship" title="World Rally Championship">World Rally Championship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Drivers from Japan have victories at the <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_500" title="Indianapolis 500">Indianapolis 500</a> and the <a href="/wiki/24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="24 Hours of Le Mans">24 Hours of Le Mans</a> as well as podium finishes in Formula One, in addition to success in domestic championships.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Super_GT" title="Super GT">Super GT</a> is the most popular national racing series in Japan, while <a href="/wiki/Super_Formula_Championship" title="Super Formula Championship">Super Formula</a> is the top-level domestic open-wheel series.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country hosts major races such as the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Grand_Prix" title="Japanese Grand Prix">Japanese Grand Prix</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p><p>Japan hosted the Summer Olympics in <a href="/wiki/1964_Summer_Olympics" title="1964 Summer Olympics">Tokyo in 1964</a> and the Winter Olympics in <a href="/wiki/1972_Winter_Olympics" title="1972 Winter Olympics">Sapporo in 1972</a> and <a href="/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics" title="1998 Winter Olympics">Nagano in 1998</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country hosted the official <a href="/wiki/2006_Basketball_World_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="2006 Basketball World Championship">2006 Basketball World Championship</a><sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and co-hosted the <a href="/wiki/2023_Basketball_World_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="2023 Basketball World Championship">2023 Basketball World Championship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Tokyo hosted the <a href="/wiki/2020_Summer_Olympics" title="2020 Summer Olympics">2020 Summer Olympics</a> in 2021, making Tokyo the first Asian city to host the Olympics twice.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The country gained the hosting rights for the official <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Volleyball_World_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="Women's Volleyball World Championship">Women's Volleyball World Championship</a> on five occasions, more than any other country.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan is the most successful Asian <a href="/wiki/Rugby_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Rugby Union">Rugby Union</a> country<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and hosted the 2019 IRB <a href="/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup" title="Rugby World Cup">Rugby World Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
    </p>
    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2></div>
    <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239009302">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0;margin:0.5em 0;display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;list-style:none}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:1px solid var(--border-color-base,#a2a9b1);padding:0.1em;background:var(--background-color-neutral-subtle,#f8f9fa)}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-entry{display:table-row;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;height:1.9em;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-image{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox-link{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .portalleft{clear:left;float:left;margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalright{clear:right;float:right;margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}}</style><ul role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portalbox portalborder portalright">
    <li class="portalbox-entry"><span class="portalbox-image"><span class="mw-image-border noviewer" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/32px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="21" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/48px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/64px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600"></span></span></span><span class="portalbox-link"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Japan" title="Portal:Japan">Japan portal</a></span></li></ul>

    <div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Notes">Notes</h2></div>

aria-label="Play audio" title="Play audio" class="oo-ui-buttonElement-button"><span class="oo-ui-iconElement-icon oo-ui-icon-volumeUp"></span><span class="oo-ui-labelElement-label"></span><span class="oo-ui-indicatorElement-indicator oo-ui-indicatorElement-noIndicator"></span></a></span><sup class="ext-phonos-attribution noexcerpt navigation-not-searchable"><a href="/wiki/File:Ja-nippon(%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC).ogg" title="File:Ja-nippon().ogg"></a></sup></span></span>, formally <span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span>, <i><span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">Nihon-koku</i></span> or <span title="Japanese-language romanization"><i lang="ja-Latn">Nippon-koku</i></span></i>. In Japanese, the name of the country as it appears on official documents, including <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">the country's constitution</a>, is <span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span>, meaning "State of Japan". The short name <span title="Japanese-language text"><span lang="ja"></span></span> is also often used officially. In English, the official name of the country is simply "Japan".<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></span>
    </li>
    </ol></div></div>
    <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1239543626"><div class="reflist">
    </div>

    </li>

    <li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/jomo/hd_jomo.htm">"Jmon Culture (ca. 10,500ca. 300 B.C.)"</a>.     <li id="cite_note-Courtiers-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Courtiers_33-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Courtiers_33-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Courtiers_33-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Courtiers_33-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Courtiers_33-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Courtiers_33-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Courtiers_33-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFHenshall,_Kenneth2012" class="citation book cs1">Henshall, Kenneth (2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=p5OL-k7A4mAC&amp;pg=PT40">"Of Courtiers and Warriors: Early and Medieval History (7101600)"</a>. <i>A History of Japan: From Stone Age to Superpower</i>.     <li id="cite_note-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-63" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFYoung2024" class="citation book cs1">Young, Louise (2024).     <li id="cite_note-water-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-water_78-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180126130519/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/english/policy/health/water_supply/1.html">"Water Supply in Japan"</a>. Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.mhlw.go.jp/english/policy/health/water_supply/1.html">the original</a> on January 26, 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">.     </li>
    <li id="cite_note-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-79" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFIwashita2011" class="citation journal cs1">Iwashita, Akihiro (2011).     <li id="cite_note-wri-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-wri_92-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://collections.unu.edu/view/UNU:5763#viewMetadata">"World Risk Report 2016"</a>. UNU-EHS. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200923203844/https://collections.unu.edu/view/UNU:5763#viewMetadata">Archived</a> from the original on September 23, 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">.     <li id="cite_note-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-121" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFKanamori1999" class="citation journal cs1">Kanamori, Shigenari (January 1, 1999).     <li id="cite_note-anomalous-constitution-122"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-anomalous-constitution_122-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFMcElwain2017" class="citation news cs1">McElwain, Kenneth Mori (August 15, 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a05602/the-anomalous-life-of-the-japanese-constitution.html">"The Anomalous Life of the Japanese Constitution"</a>. <i>Nippon.com</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190811213143/https://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a05602/the-anomalous-life-of-the-japanese-constitution.html">Archived</a> from the original on August 11, 2019.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nippon.com&amp;rft.atitle=The+Anomalous+Life+of+the+Japanese+Constitution&amp;rft.date=2017-08-15&amp;rft.aulast=McElwain&amp;rft.aufirst=Kenneth+Mori&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nippon.com%2Fen%2Fin-depth%2Fa05602%2Fthe-anomalous-life-of-the-japanese-constitution.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJapan" class="Z3988"></span></span>

    <li id="cite_note-123"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-123" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.kantei.go.jp/foreign/judiciary/0620system.html">"The Japanese Judicial System"</a>. Office of the Prime Minister of Japan.     <li id="cite_note-SIPRI-2020-139"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-SIPRI-2020_139-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.sipri.org/sites/default/files/2023-04/2304_fs_milex_2022.pdf">"Trends in World Military Expenditure, 2022"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a>.     </li>
    <li id="cite_note-WTOB-181"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WTOB_181-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WTOB_181-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation journal cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.18111%2Fwtobarometereng.2020.18.1.5">"Statistical Annex"</a>. <i>UNWTO World Tourism Barometer</i>. <b>18</b> (5): 18.     <li id="cite_note-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-213" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110430010519/http://www.japancorp.net/Article.Asp?Art_ID=15429">"Japan Successfully Launches Lunar Explorer 'Kaguya'<span class="cs1-kern-right"></span>"</a>.     <li id="cite_note-228"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-228" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mhlw.go.jp/english/policy/health/water_supply/dl/3-1a.pdf">"Waterworks Vision Summary"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. June 2004. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20211006212730/http://www.mhlw.go.jp/english/policy/health/water_supply/dl/3-1a.pdf">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on October 6, 2021.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Waterworks+Vision+Summary&amp;rft.pub=Ministry+of+Health%2C+Labour+and+Welfare&amp;rft.date=2004-06&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mhlw.go.jp%2Fenglish%2Fpolicy%2Fhealth%2Fwater_supply%2Fdl%2F3-1a.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJapan" class="Z3988"></span></span>

    <li id="cite_note-229"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-229" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jwwa.or.jp/jigyou/kaigai_file/2017WaterSupplyInJapan.pdf">"Water Supply in Japan 2017"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>.     <li id="cite_note-UN_Worlds_Cities-243"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-UN_Worlds_Cities_243-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/publications/pdf/urbanization/the_worlds_cities_in_2016_data_booklet.pdf">"The World's Cities in 2016"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. United Nations. March 12, 2017. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170112211410/http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/publications/pdf/urbanization/the_worlds_cities_in_2016_data_booklet.pdf">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on January 12, 2017.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+World%27s+Cities+in+2016&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations&amp;rft.date=2017-03-12&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.un.org%2Fen%2Fdevelopment%2Fdesa%2Fpopulation%2Fpublications%2Fpdf%2Furbanization%2Fthe_worlds_cities_in_2016_data_booklet.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJapan" class="Z3988"></span></span>
